description:
A wine bar that combines some of the best eats at the Ferry Plaza... I don't think I could ask for more than Cowgirl Creamery's Mt. Tam, cured meat from Boccalone and Prather Ranch; satisfyingly complete with a glass of wine ... or two.
This adorable little liquor shop includes a bar and just a few high-top tables for patrons to enjoy drinks and relax.

$31.75 Italian Salumi & Cowgirl Cheese Combo - 5 oz. half round of Mt. Tam,  Prather Ranch Soppressata, Boccalone Lonza, Prather Ranch Country Ham, w/ Boccalone whole grain mustard, olive mix, Acme Epi baguette, McQuade's Celtic Fig & Ginger Chutney:
My friend and I shared this platter along with a couple glasses of white and red. I don't remember which wines we had, but they were delicious.
Our waiter recommended us some excellent choices.
It's been a while since I've had Mt. Tam triple-cream cheese. It is just as smooth and buttery as I remember. The Acme epi is one of my favorite breads as well, as it is wonderfully fluffy with a soft chew. It really is an excellent combination.
The soppressata had a chewier texture, while the lonza was more delicate, and the country ham was sliced super thin. The fig and chutney were nice accoutrements, but I usually don't feel the need to add on. The bread, cheese, and meat are already so good together. 

I'm sure I'll be back to enjoy more wine in the future. Perhaps next time I'll try the burrata as well.
author: Joy W.

description:
**** Review 96 ****
Delicious local wine, and some beers. If you're looking for a nice place for a quick stop and "Hydration" this is a place to try. For the locals, they offer a wine club, for the tourist they sell wine travel bags. Make sure this is one of your stops during your visit to the Ferry Building Market.
author: Luis S.

description:
It was Saturday, and we decided to walk to the Ferry Building from Union Square.  Great walk and fun seeing all these Santas and Santa's helpers all around.  Little did we know that it was Santa Con.  Lots of shoppers out and about, and there was a farmers market at the FB, but instead of walking around, we went inside...

Me: Oh, a wine merchant...

We decided to grab a seat at the bar and the friendly bartender recommended this brut rose from France.  Sold!  After all, it is our birthday weekend!  So there were were, sipping our champagne and at some point started talking about work....whaaaaat???  Talk about buzzkill...LOL!

Ok, then we started talking about what to do the rest of the day which ranged from cable cars, Alcatraz, Coit Tower, Fisherman's Wharf...which we walked to.  Great list of wines to choose from and also a great place to start your day!
author: Mikey H.

description:
I might have had a little too much fun drinking wine, chowing on olives and writing emails at the bar of The Wine Merchant in the Ferry Building this past Sunday. Full discretion: I've been thinking about those olives since. 

This was my second visit to this wine market and bar located in the middle section of the ferry building. I have to say, I was super impressed by the Sunday afternoon energy you'll find throughout the entire market. It appears that everyone in San Fran loves to drink and eat ice cream on Sunday afternoons. I can get on board with that.

I was nervous about lugging my laptop on the bar and wanted to make certain I was "earning my time and spot." I ordered a full glass of a Californian wine (5 oz. pour/loved it/forgetting the name but remembering the price of $13.75), followed by the green olives ($7- generous serving and so damn good) and a white wine sample. I know, my wine prowess is sounding super elementary right now so do me a favor and focus on the fact that I loved the energy, what I sampled and the atmosphere.

Note that this is part bar and part shop so you can pick up chilled bottles or join their rose club while you're there as well. The bar space is on the cozy (aka small) size but it does the job. I'll certainly return during my next work trip.
author: Brittany S.

description: I just love it here, my favorite way to get to the ferry building is by taking the ferry, we usually come from Larkspar and on a beautiful day it just doesn't get better than that! And the first place we go is to the wine merchant, you can order any number of wines and champagnes (we always get a Bottle!) and you can just sit there and people watch from the tables, they always have something delicious to snack on and my bestie and I we always order some French champagne  and the last couple of times we've been there we got the same guy Jason a real sweetie pie and we love having a good chat with him about champagne travel and all the wonderful things to do and eat nearby, we love us some Jason  he even remembered us from our last visit aww The ferry building has so many wonderful places to eat drink and shop yay all my absolute favorite things to do! Cheers    SYOY
author: Mina G.

description:
Excellent Barbera from Piemonte, Italy - I would definitely order it again. It was smooth and paired very nicely with the goat cheese that we ordered and the French charcuterie plate. The fig and ginger chutney was also an amazing addition to the light meal after work. 

I will most definitely come back!
author: Josie C.

description: Came in here on a whim just looking.  That lead to walking out with two bottles of wine.  Good selection from both local and international.  A little pricey but that is to be expected as this is a touristy area.
author: Brigid D.

description:
After getting lunch at Hog Island, my boyfriend and I were on the hunt for some wine to take up to Fairfax for a wedding. (Not to gift, but to drink while we got ready for a wedding. Classy, I know.)

We walked around the Ferry Building and lo and behold, found a wine bar! With so many different options, one of the employees gave us some recommendations, and promptly rang us up. Service was awesome, and the bottle of wine she recommended was even better! Glad to know I can find some good wine here. Cheers!
author: Christine S.

description:
The Ferry Plaza Wine Merchant is a terrific spot to enjoy a sampling of various wines, enjoy a flight or simply a glass while enjoying the small bites from a host of other merchants.

The cheese plates are reasonable and quite good. The staff is knowledgeable, friendly and efficient considering the considerable foot traffic that is the Ferry Building.

The location at the Ferry Building is excellent for an after work glass of wine with friends or casual weekend tasting while enjoying he Farmers Market with afternoon shopping.
author: Michael G.

description:
Every time I come into the Ferry Building I wonder why I don't come in more often. I work across the damn street basically.  

Fantastic wine selection!!! Lots of great local stuff and all reasonably priced. We got a bottle and hung for a nice hour. Passed on the small bites they have regrettably. But next time will check em out! 

If you can get a little table there it's a great time. A little loud and not super comfortable seating, but overall pretty chill spot and you can look at some wines on the wall instead of the people you're hanging with.
author: Sean M.

description: Checked out the Ferry Plaza today because I had some time to kill and needed somewhere to sit to do a bit of work. Was close by the ferry building and last time I was in there, I saw this place (at the time it was packed) & wanted to come back to check it out. Glad I did! Great wine selection. I asked the winetender which choice to pick between Pinot Blanc & the Betty - picked the Blanc & it was delicious. I wish they had smaller cheese plates available - I was alone at that time & didn't want a whole board of cheese to myself. However FREE WIFI for the win  I'll be back!
author: Alexa S.

description: Great wine selection, fun place to hang out and very busy.  If you can grab a seat, do so, but not before grabbing a bottle from the shelves to have them crack open.  People watching here is great and Debbie is awesome!
author: Sheryl M.

description:
I'm not a big wine drinker (or a big drinker in general), but this place is great if you want some exposure to different wines and try exploring options. Located in the Ferry Building, this place has a commercial Napa-esque wine tasting feel with limited bar and table seating, but TONS of choices. The bartenders here are also patient and informative - explaining the wines and tastes clearly to me before I decided which ones I wanted to taste. 

Space is a little tight, do-able if you have a small group. I had a great time here with my date and the bartender the other day,  just sampling some wine (and beer) along with a cheese pairing. Food is pretty light here - nothing I wouldn't consider a whole meal. But huge plus: you get to bring your own food in here to dine!
author: Rebecca L.

description: What a fun place to find!  After walking around awhile, we needed a nice glass of wine and cheese.  This was perfect.  We were greeted with a friendly server (I can't remember his name but young, dark hair and glasses) and brought a delicious glass of rose!  We also tried the petit Verdot which was awesome!  A great place to take a break and enjoy good wine and cheese.  ( the Gouda was to die for!!!)
author: Jules M.

description: My experience at the wine merchant was well below average. The bartender / server was borderline rude, did not make eye contact with our table the entire night, and had an air of arrogance I could just not deal with. The wine selection was fine and I have to say I was quite surprised they had such an extensive beer list. All in all, I would not go back based on the service. It was not memorable. Save your money folks
author: Kora L.

description: I've been meaning to write this review for a while, but I had hoped things would get better. Sadly, they have not improved. My work colleagues and I liked to stop by for a quick glass (or two) of wine before heading home to Marin. We enjoyed talking to the sommelier about the lovely wines they carry and enjoyed the tastes they would share with us and would often purchase a bottle or two to bring home.  However, the last few times we stopped in one of their employees would also be at the bar and was so drunk and obnoxious we stopped coming. I don't know her name, but she is a heavy set woman with blond hair. I guess she is in her sixties. She was really flirtatious with my male co-workers and was really inappropriate with her comments. She seems to be a permanent fixture at the bar and is just awful. I hope the people who own the place see this comment and do something about her presence. We won't be back again until she is gone.
author: Joni M.

description:
TLDR: If you're already in the area, Ferry Plaza Wine Merchant is an enjoyable place to shop or have a drink and a nibble.

The way they've got it set up, Ferry Plaza Wine Merchant feels like an improved take on the airport wine bar.

You can't knock them for selection; there's a bit of everything on the walls, on shelves, in stacks, in coolers, and of course on the current tasting menu. I had a dry, fruity Spanish white followed by a fruity, metallic Spanish red. Nothing exceptional, which is why I didn't note the names, but I appreciated the experience. I also ordered some of the Mt Tam from Cowgirl Creamery, which came with Acme bread and a raisin and fig compote. Simple, predictable, but well-done and delicious.

God bless tourists, but I think we can all agree that milling groups do not make for a chill and sophisticated ambiance. That, combined with the fact that Ferry Plaza Wine Merchant is 50-50 bar and vendor, is enough to push me towards trying other wine bars in SF.
author: Lane B.

description:
You can't kill time.  You just can't.  But were you to give it a go, to stab it with your steely knives, here would be maybe one of the best nearby places to have at it.

I have different spots to frequent with my different friends.  This is my spot for Davey reunions.  We sail from our respective cities, him from Dragonstone and me from Braavos for our regular visit except during Lent when we still visit but it is anything but regular for me.  The bar mistress let me sniff his beer before he arrived yesterday and we didn't let on so he did not know that some of the fragrance was missing.

The Ferry Building has faults that folks that like to find fault with everything would find but so what.  Few things are perfect and there's much to be thankful for so why not do that instead.

To sit at one of the stools facing out or one of the tables by the main FB walking area and sip and catch up is pretty much one of the most pleasant times one can have irrespective the sum or the setting.  It's just chill, is all.  A wide variety of reasonably priced vintages, beer that they've chosen because they think we'll like it not because it's what everybody else pushes, cheese and meats and the Acme torpedo baguettes if you're peckish.

The staff knows their stuff, are attentive but not in your business, quick with a smile or advice or an answer to a question.  Yesterday the flaxen-haired maiden was almost elvish in her green and we smiled a secret smile as I stuck my nose in Davey's beer.

If you've not gone please make a point.  Go.  This is a simple thing in life.  Give it a try.  Cheers.
author: Markus N.

description: I like this place. Extensive and unusual wine selection, even by the glass. Good bottle prices, and a wide variety of price points makes for a nice selection to pick from. Great apps menu at the wine bar - love the caviar service! The staff is extremely knowledgeable, and won't try to oversell you.  If you love wine, you need to visit this place.
author: Matthew B.

description: After an overwhelming walk through the market, finally a place to sit with great service. We had seats at the bar. Excellent wine flight perfectly paired with this month's cheeses. Totally worth doing!
author: Carrie B.

description:
The wine selection here is huge. And if you're not a wine person, then the wine merchant also has plenty of beers to offer as well. I usually prefer beer, but I decided to opt for wine. The bartender was informative and patient. He explained the wines and tastes clearly, and he helped me make a great wine choice.

It was nice that they let patrons bring food from elsewhere while enjoying one of their beverages since the wine merchant seemed to have the best selection of wines and beers in the marketplace.
author: Joseph T.

description: Nice location and great wines. My bartender was a little checked out and not very friendly, which would have typically rubbed me the wrong way,  but I needed some ME time, and being left alone worked to my advantage.
author: Katherine G.

description:
Are you waiting to catch the Ferry? 

How about...

A) Have a glass of wine or bubbly at the Ferry Plaza Wine Merchant
B) Snack on something light and tasty
C) People watch
D) All of the above

You can do all of above things at the Ferry Plaza Wine Merchant. Trust me, its worth it and I promise it is not pricey. Kthanksbye!
author: Owie N.

description: Martha V. your name should be in lights. Your knowledge and attitude convinced me that I had come to the right place for a great choice in wine. I was meeting my friend for a lunch at the Slanted Door and I stopped by to check on a "blind wine tasting" for Christmas. Martha was there working hard when I interrupted and requested her help. Martha was so gracious to stop and show me (a NON connoisseur of wine) some wine of her preference and taste. Since I was in over my head, I told Martha that I would have lunch and return with my friend (a connoisseur of wine) and he would also help me with a choice. What a Great experience to hear the two of them discuss the choices of 4 wines. They eliminated one wine at a time and ended up with the best choice, a 2015 Turley Zinfandel. I'll win the "blind wine tasting" because the Sommelier said so. . . Thanks Martha. . .
author: John94521 H.

description: Came here with some Philly friends/recent transplants to SF. Wine was awesome and our server was friendly and very knowledgeable. Would love to come back when the rest of the market is open. It's a pretty neat place- like an upscale Reading Terminal.
author: Orrin E.

description: This place is great for locals and tourist alike. Glen behind the bar poured me a phenomenal Pinot noir that I was almost certain I wouldn't like. I tried it because he insisted, it was amazing. What a great experience.
author: Curtis G.

description:
This is my to-go place when I miss the ferry. That said, I always come here by myself and so I never struggle to find a place as there's always room at the bar for one person. If, however, you're with a larger group, you may have to wait a little as this place is busy - especially after work. 

Despite this being a wine place, I also like to order a beer once in a while and if I really want to treat myself, I get one of their olive plates.
author: Uli B.

description:
Came in for a vintage that my boyfriend and I shared on our first Valentine's day together. According to their website, this is the only vendor in the city (and as far as I'm concerned - online too) that carries it. It was fairly inexpensive but I was more concerned with the sentimental value. They were out of stock but thankfully, SARAH came to the rescue. She ordered it and had it in the store within a day. Excellent communication, emailed me back and forth to confirm that they would have it in time. 

As far as the rest of the staff - a little lackluster. I had to wait around for close to 45 minutes for her to arrive to inform her coworkers that I did in fact reserve a bottle. But all in all, I am so grateful. Thank you Sarah for saving the day!
author: Erin S.

description:
One of my favorite things to do in San Fransisco! Love this place! They have great wine and a very unique selection. I love ordering their flights because they always feature some new and interesting wines. I like they they aren't all high priced and allow you to fall in love with a new bottle that's reasonably priced. They are very knowledgable about the wine selections and are super friendly. They also don't mind if you bring in some food from outside whiles you sit and sip. 

It's a great atmosphere and great location. Each visit is always a different experience. Love love love!
author: Jordan M.

description:
Let's say that you're at the ferry building, stocking up on provisions.

You start to feel like maybe having a glass of wine.
Or, maybe a flight.

It's totally ok, it's almost 5:00.

What should you do?  You should head to the Ferry Plaza Wine Merchant.

Why?

Because they actually encourage you to nosh on your just purchased ACME bread, Cowgirl Creamery cheeses, & Recchiuti chocolates...right here in their shop.

How accommodating is that?

In case you haven't been shopping in the market yet, don't fret.  They have their own small bites, along w a wine to go with every reason & season.
They do meat (boccalone) & cheese (cowgirl) platters, w acme bread, of course.

And if you're the sort to join a wine club, you can do that here, too.

Order wine off the menu, do a flight, or, buy a bottle & drink it here.  This is your party.

Service is upbeat & knowledgable, but if it's rush hour, there'll be a wait for things, & table cleanup can be painfully slow.

Hang in there & sip your wine.

4 stars.
author: Veronica M.

description: Jason is great! Awesome way to experience the Ferry Building vibes. Go get your wine on.
author: Yad L.

description: Love the wine merchant! It's a good place to stop when you first get into the city for a snack and a beer or glass of wine. Small plates and good service. It's a bit pricey but I think it's worth it. Nice treat every once in a while!
author: Nick B.

description:
I had been here for drinks before, but not food so I owed it a review.  Ferry Plaza Wine Merchant is located in, you guessed it, the Ferry Plaza building in SF.  In addition to wines, WM also offers local beers, meat from Boccalone, cheese from Cowgirl, and bread from Acme:  What a great way to enjoy all four vendors at one location!

We ordered the Boccalone salumi and Cowgirl cheese ($29.95).  The charcuterie also came w/ Acme bread, olives, and peach chutney.  First of all, the salumi was outstanding!  The flavor of Chris Constantino's craft salumi shined:  5 Stars.  In addition, the creaminess of the cheese contrasted nicely against the salumi:  5 Stars.  Acme didn't disappoint either, and the bread was crusty on the outside, and chewy on the inside:  5 Stars.  Lastly, the olives and chutney were also very good.  The only downside was the plate needed more mustard, and I asked for no chutney, and replace w/ nuts:  4 Stars.  To drink, she had a grenache from France ($10), while I had a schiava from Italy ($8.25).  The grenache is a little heavier and it was exactly what she was looking for.  The schiava is a lighter wine from a thin skinned, larger grape.  It was perfect for me on a hot day:  Both 4 Stars.

The ambiance is very nice.  In addition to the retail store, there are a few seats at both sides of the bar, some high seats facing outward, and a few high seats along the main part of the Ferry building.  The only downside was there wasn't a smaller charcuterie plate:  It was a lot of food for two people:  4 Stars.  Regarding the service, there was room for improvement.  The bartender was friendly, but he took a while to acknowledge us.  In addition, our food came out after another couple that arrived well after us.  Lastly, the bartender didn't give her a place setting:  3 Stars for the bartender, 2 Stars for the kitchen.  

I would have rated this place a 4, other than the fact that I met a Korean girl here.  We had met the night before (Valentine's Day), and promised each other that if we showed up here the next day, we would exchange numbers.  Well we both showed, and I couldn't have had a better time.  So some times, the rating is not all about the food, ambiance or service.  Whom you have a meal and glass of wine with is just as important - LMAO!!!
author: Joe P.

description: Cold bread. Cold hummus. While there is an extensive selection of wine the manner in which staff serve the wine is poor. When purchasing by the glass there is no tasting or presentation of the bottle to ascertain it's origin.
author: S Y.

description:
I just got off the phone with Carter and can tell you, having a wine merchant that can read your mind is as good as it gets.  I live in Texas and among the many lovely idiosyncrasies of the Lone Star State is the one about people sending us booze.  There's all kinds of laws and prohibitions and rules so most places won't even fool with it to start.  In fact, entire states just can't or won't.  If you filter on winesearcher.com for "ships to Texas", you get three hits.  

Ferry Plaza however, not only ships to Texas, but if you buy 12, you get the 10% case discount.  Which you should do anyway cause the only drag about having wine delivered to your door is you must be there to receive it, so it's cheaper by the dozen in both dollars and cents, like pa"tience" for waiting around for the UPS person...If you only ordered 6, you'd have to do that twice as often.  No, thank you.

Now, the reason I had the privilege to speak to Carter today was that one of the wines I'd ordered to round out my mixed dozen was actually sold out and rather than miss the one day a week "ship to Texas" special delivery window, he figured I probably really wanted the brut rose that I'd ordered 9 bottles of and didn't really care about the rando other whites I'd chosen so round out the dozen, so he nixed the out of stock bottle, kept the discounts, and my birthday rose is on it's way to me as we speak!  Fabulous!

In addition to great customer service in a clutch, I really like their website.  They have this handy trademarked Wine Profile tool that you can use to search for wines based on six characteristics: type, sweetness, intensity, body, wood, & farming.  And the profiler explains what each characteristic is and the different levels in each.  I found some of these align to my De Long's Wine Grape Varietal Table, but some, like farming and wood, are unique to FPWM's site.  You could also look up wines you like on their site and see what the values are then do a search based on that (what would be cool is to do a backwards search from a wine you already like that has the same values, it would save a step, but not a big deal either way).

There are also many other ways to search and filter, and they have different categories, like "New Arrivals", "Wines Under $20", and "Merchants Picks" although I think I broke the website looking for still wines from Hungary...  Plus they have a monthly wine club and events and a wine bar on site.  FPWM is tops and eventually, I'll have a happy, sad, or regular face in every square of my De Long's with FPWM's help!
author: Melissa A.

description: Yes, the wine is great. And surprisingly affordable for being in a touristy area. The highlight is the knowledgeable and fun people who work there. This was our third visit and Steve took care of us today. Excellent!
author: Ed S.

description:
I've been coming here almost weekly, for over a year, stopping for a glass of wine before boarding my ferry to Larkspur. The staff is very friendly, the ambiance comfortable and the wines quite nice. Up until a month or so ago, I could have a nice glass of white wine, with the "fee," tax and a decent tip, it cost me $10.  Then, a few weeks ago, the wine menu changed...then for a similar glass of wine, with fees, tax and tip, it cost me $14.  The menu changed again...now, for a similar glass of wine, with the fee, tax and tip, it cost me $16. I'm sorry, I think that is outrageous. It appears to me that you are taking advantage of the tourists and ignoring the locals (except the very wealthy). Such a shame. I will not go back. 

Ken
author: Ken B.

description: The Ferry Plaza is a great place to hang out with people who are visiting from out of town. My sister and I enjoyed strolling through the Ferry building and we came across the Wine Merchant. We peeked in to realize there was a wine bar! We enjoyed a few glasses of wine prior to having dinner at the Wharf. The establishment offers self seating, unless they have a full house and they form a line outside the bar. The waiter was knowledgeable about the wine, as he was able to offer suggestions based on wines we enjoyed in the past. I enjoyed a glass of the 2013 Chardonnay from Sonoma Coast, CA. It was crisp and had a light citric after taste. My sister enjoyed the 2014 Chateau d'Esclans Whispering Angel Rose.
author: Sarin P.

description: Great service (super friendly staff) and an excellent selection of wine that changes a bit over time so there is always something new to try. The burrata is also amazing and the bread is heavenly! Get a table in the main Ferry Building hallway to enjoy some sunlight.
author: Eggert B.

description: I used to come here after my shift when I worked in the financial district. The selection is great and is at a fair price point. There is limited seating, so I do not recommend this place for large groups. Also, it is located in a tourist area, so avoid going Fri and Sat. Otherwise, it will be extremely loud and crowded. All of the times that I went during the week, there were only about 5 other people there and it was a chill, relaxing environment.
author: Christina S.

description:
On a Friday afternoon, this place is brimming with locals eager to ease into the weekend with a classy bev. I'm impressed by how comfortable & real the bar feels, despite its location in the heart of the Ferry Building.  Also, the prices are not grossly inflated for tourist wallets. $12 for a glass of bubbly works for me. Next time I miss the ferry, I'll fret not and belly up to the bar for a quick glass. 

Wines are offered by the 2 oz taste, 5 oz glass, half bottles, and full bottles. Buy a bottle in the shop and pay just $9 to drink it on-site. Surprisingly, their beer selection is pretty monstrous too: 50+ bottles to choose from!
author: Nique F.

description:
Nice place to take a break from the ferry-building bustle to have a drink/snack. 

I wish the a/c was cranked on a little higher (we were sweating in the back corner of a particularly warm SF afternoon). The bottle of champagne and cheese plate  was quite tasty, but we felt the server was trying to rush us right when we sat down. He never smiled and didn't go beyond taking and dropping off our order (and receipt later on).

Don't expect nice service, and expect to pay $$$ for some soft cheese and bread rolls. It's a decent location to rest your feet from the ferry building madness.
author: Tila T.

description:
It's self-seating once you come in, with the choice of sitting at tables or at the bar. 

The menu is fairly simple, several wines, red wines, white wines, sweet wines, etc. There are different prices for the amount of wine you taste. They even have nonalcoholic drinks but you have to ask the server about it. On the back of the menu they have foods to pair with your wines. Meats, cheeses, bread, etc.

I love the sweet stuff, and moscato is one of my favorite kinds of wine, so I got the Centorri Moscato ($6.95 for one 5oz glass). I really like this wine and how it's kinda like sparkling cider. The alcohol is there but it isn't too strong and it's bubbly to the throat a bit.

I also got a small Italian meat platter ($8.95). This came with slices of salami and mild coppa with olives and mushrooms drizzled with a Italian dressing. I actually like how well this platter paired with the moscato. I like that combination of salty and sweet, and the Italian dressing really made the sweetness of the moscato pop.

Of course, wineries are always expensive, but this is a fun experience if you're down to try a simple glass or two.
author: Jerianne G.

description:
Wine wine wine!! If you love wine, and even if you DONT love wine this place has most of it all!!

My friends wanted to try all the bars in the ferry - piers area for their trip and this was our first stop. We did not expect much, other than wine and wine, maybe cheese - but mostly wine.

Our waiter was awesome, super nice and friendly. His recommendations were on point! My friend does not like wine, so she was recommended this sparkling moscatio, which she fell in love with. Had two glasses!

Their list may be small and limited; however, if you want to know more about wine and grow into that community I suggest you start somewhere and if you're in the SF area might as well start here! They know what they are talking about!

They also have meat and cheese dishes which you can have with your wine. The place is located inside the ferry building and so you can eat, drink and people watch to your extent!

They also have portable battery chargers for android and iphones!! Super cool.

Great area, great services and good wine though it was limited.
author: -Johnson- N.

description: Great selection of wines and beers bit horrid service while sitting at the bar. I had two beers and observed absolutely NO eye contact, greetings, nor conversations with me nor any of the customers. No "how are you doing or what would you like to drink". Nothing. When they cashed me out they were completely MUTE. Pathetic and robotic. I suppose they think everybody is a tourist and not local. I won't return. The staff needs a strong class on Customer Service 101.
author: Michael P.

description:
Great little wine & beer bar with seating around the bar or "spectator" high top tables out front for people watching in San Francisco's always busy Ferry Building.  The market itself is in the back and side area of the bar.  They boast a good selection of both wine and beer for the non-wine drinker in your group.  Wine lovers have their choice of a 2oz. pour,  a 6 oz., or the bottle.  I chose to start with a 2 oz. rose, then moved on to a 2oz. Spanish White and ended with my favorite Pinot Noir.  
I omitted two stars from my review simply because the only options for small bites to enjoy with the wine was crusty bread loafs made with white flour, different types of cheeses and cured meats.  Sadly all things that I've chosen lately to avoid.  I would have loved to see fresh fruit and almonds on the menu as well.  
The service was adequate, the ambiance, what you would expect it to be, meaning perfect for a wine market & bar in the Ferry Building.  I could have linger longer, but did not wish to have any more wine!  
San Francisco's Ferry Building is one of my favorite places to go when in the city, and I will certainly be enjoying a glass of wine here again soon!
author: Winny S.

description: Terrible customer service, you can be buying tastes while people next to you get a bunch of tastes for free
author: E C.

description:
Sitting here not having a whole lot of fun.

They have this confusing note at the bottom of the menu "All wines served at the bar reflect a $9 corkage per bottle. Feel free to select your own bottle from the retail store and pay $9 corkage fee to drink in the bar."

While waiting in line to be seated, I spied a bottle that interested me in the attached adjacent retail store which is where you wait in line.

I didn't see any glasses of Cabernet that interested me on the menu and was put off by the glass prices for a 5oz pour, so I asked the waitress to clarify the above quoted line. I asked, does that mean I can buy a $12 bottle and pay a $9 corkage fee? She said yes, so I got up, went into the wine store area, bought a bottle and brought it back to the table. 

Well did I get snapped at. I was told that I was supposed to buy it from her. 

She did let me drink from the bottle I bought and the wine I did buy was delicious, but when I am tired and just want to relax, I really don't need all the confusion reading a poorly written menu or a snappish waitress when I try to follow their written instructions and fail. I didn't like being made to feel like an idiot in from or other customers.
author: Kate W.

description: This is a great post work HH spot! They have a large selection of old and new world wines. They also serve small bites. Great people watching too!
author: Stephanie C.

description: So many wines and beers to choose from with delicous cheese and bread plates to pair with the drinks as a mid day snack. We walked in getting lucky with an empty table, it was pretty packed. I love cheese and beer. Yes, not cheese and wine. It works! Located inside the pier, will not be dissapointed.
author: Jessica W.

description: A sizeable assortment of wine and good ambiance and location to either people watch or watch the TV. Service was good. We ordered a glass of their Green and Red Zinfandel ($13) and tthe Kukkula lagniappe ($10) with an Italian meat plate to share ($9). We also had a cheese plate from Cowgirl Creamery that we brought. Definitely do not order the Italian meat plate - it's basically cold cuts and not very good ones. The wine was good but not aerated, which is a pity for a wine bar.
author: Judy S.

description: I've come here twice in this last year and the bartenders on both occassions have offered very slow service with frankly, shocking and quite dissappointingly poor, condescending attitudes. They seem to be annoyed to be there because they probably think they are doing you a favor or something. I even purchased a bottle of wine after my 2nd visit because the wine I had was so good. So I am going to give them one last try to see if they get rid of their poor attitude. Guys this is a business, you need customers to thrive, lose the attitude at the bar please.
author: Luis S.

description:
The Ferry Building on the Embarcadero is somewhat of a crossroads of the world and a little community unto itself at the same time. The hallways are always packed with locals, tourists, and weekly grocery shoppers seeking out some of the best independently owned boutiques in the city.

Most of the "stores" in the Ferry Building are walk-up kiosks or nooks that are decorated in hopes of standing out from the crowd. The Wine Merchant is probably one of the biggest stores with countless wine bottles covering the walls, fine cheeses, and small tables in the center. If you're lucky you can try to snag a table on the small patio for some of the best people watching in the city!

Somehow, on an extremely busy holiday weekend, our party of six got an open table in the back corner. We drooled over the menu before finally ordering a few beers, some glasses of wine, and a cheese platter with fresh baked baguette. Remember how the building is like a small community? The cheeses (one cow and one goat) came from Cowgirl Creamery and the baguette came from Acme Bread Co., both of which have stores down the hall!

If you're looking to give your feet a rest and your liver a workout, the Wine Merchant is great! The wine and delicious cheeses cause you to basically forget that you're trapped in the center of one of the busiest markets in San Francisco!
author: Kevin R.

description: This place was supposed to be open another hour, but we were turned away because "it's a slow night" while there are 17 people sitting right there in front of us drinking... please don't go to this place, they don't deserve the patronage...
author: Sac D.

description: A-OK service, nice wine selection, relaxing place to have a glass of wine.
author: Reyn J.

description:
Situated inside the Ferry Building, this is a nice wine bar in a fun location if you enjoy people watching.  I rarely come to the Ferry Building, so it was a treat to enjoy a glass of wine with Acme bread and Cowgirl Creamery cheese (Mt. Tam).  

The seating here is first come first serve.  We came on a Saturday during Farmers Market so we were lucky to find a table for three.  I had tried the Sauternes during a previous visit, but was unable to find it on their menu.  The waiter told me the menu changes from time to time, but he was able to recommend something similar (2009 Domaine de l'Ancienne Cure Monbazillac), which was just as good.

Overall, it was a great way to spend an early afternoon enjoying great wine and food with friends, and people-watching.
author: Candice H.

description:
Looking for a nice wine to take for a first meeting w/ the Sis-In-Law & her husband, I knew I wanted something impressive but didn't want to break the bank....

As the Mr & I were perusing the CA wines at Ferry Plaza Wine Merchant, there were a ton of labels I'd never heard of ( but that's nothing unusual for me )

Fortunately someone from the staff approached us & offered assistance & turned out the bottle I was holding wasn't what he would have recommended.....& have to say I trusted his judgement, after he randomly told us about this super Albarino they just got in & let us sample

It was *wunderbar* & we couldn't resist getting a bottle - for us of course b/c couldn't get something for SIL without getting something for us as well!  That would have been rude!  :-)

SIL & her Mr will be enjoying a nice Chard & we'll be enjoying another visit to Ferry Plaza Wine Merchant in the very near future
author: Adrienne G.

description:
An excellent place to get the smallest glass 
Of wine for the highest price. They have an etch on their glasses that limits it to 5 oz. 
I think that sucks. I would rather invest in the bar that be a patron. Because it's a great place to own but a lousy place to patronize.
author: Monte H.

description:
Had never been to this part of San Francisco was excited to walk around the Ferry Building Marketplace. I'm so sorry I came so late and missed most things, but was happy just to be able to wander around and enjoy some ocean views. Will DEFINITELY come back to get the full experience, but for now I'm happy to have been able to stop for a glass of wine and a nibble at the Ferry Plaza Wine Merchant. We walked right in around 7:30 on a Wednesday night and sat just outside of the actual store at the high-tops in the hallway. A gentleman came over immediately to welcome us and feel us out regarding what we were interested in (something bubbly, something refreshing, something light) so he could make exceptionally educated suggestions. I got a glass of the Vajra Moscato d'Asti ($11.25) and it was exactly what I wanted - I'm so glad the server steered me towards that one. If we hadn't somewhere else to be, I would have loved to to have tried the Cuvée de Crayères as well!

We also ordered a snack, a harder cheese with a tomato tapenade which was tasty, but because it was diced so finely was nearly impossible to spread or scoop on a knife/spoon in polite company. 

I would definitely come out of my way to come here again the next time I'm San Francisco - if you love wine (not just consuming it, but the education of it and the exploration of it), this is a great spot to enjoy a glass at. I just popped on to their website and see they do regularly change their cheese boards (I'd really like a re-do at that!), and offer a variety of wine events and wine tastings, too. Yay!
author: Steff D.

description: I like this place a lot. Been here twice and have had good experiences both times. The service is good, the wine is great, and the ambiance is nice. A bit pricey but it's in the ferry building so that is to be expected. I passed on the food here because of the prices but it all sounded really good. I would totally come back for a glass (or two) of wine
author: Ilana B.

description:
Excellent wine bar in the iconic ferry building. Great place to go in a big or small group and has an excellent wine collection. They also have a great meat and cheese collection. Nice casual vibe and being seconds away from my condo doesn't hurt either!

Must try!
author: Kabir S.

description:
They have a wide range of wine selections and over 100 types of beers! 

The customer service is great, and the people that work there are very knowledgeable. I asked for a good Cabernet  recommendation, and the employee behind the counter took us to the red wine section. He then make suggestions based on our budget range. I thought that was very helpful. 

The wine bar section is nice. You seat yourself so you can sit anywhere you want. They have a variety of cheese plates and a large selection of wine. You can even chose a wine bottle from the store section and drink it at the bar (with a corking fee of course). 

I tried their red wine flight which is about $21 for 3 different red wines. A normal bottle from these red wines range from $35-$50, so it's nice to get to try them first before actually buying any of them. Ended up getting one of the red wines from the wine flight. 

Overall a great experience! I want to come back and try their food next time to pair it with some wine!
author: Kim C.

description:
Lovely, accommodating place to park yourself and enjoy a reasonably-priced glass of wine while waiting for the ferry or to take a rest during shopping. The store is half wine bar / half wine store, with most bar options available for purchase in the store. They will also allow you to select a wine from the store and enjoy it in the bar for a modest ($9) corkage fee. 

This is definitely our favorite "kill an hour" stop when waiting around. On our last trip, we took home a couple bottles of the wine we discovered in the bar to enjoy later! 

The wine store boasts an impressive selection, many under $20, as well as a few various liquors and beers. It's a must for every Ferry Building visit!
author: Jamie S.

description: I wanted to try a charcuterie  plate and sample some cheese,  as I'm  a charcuterie /wine/cheese virgin,  though I've  tried everything separately.  I sat at the bar with  hopes of being helped along but as soon as I asked a question  about the meat platter,  I was given the cold shoulder although  other customers seemed to be accommodated nicely.   I did order a discounted cheese plate and a meat platter,  although when the person brought my order he placed the check next to it  which I thought  was odd.   I was told it was the tab.  Twenty  minutes  passed with no meat platter and no  "how is everything?"  When I asked where my platter is,  he claimed he didn't  hear me.   I gave the guy the order right to his face.  This was not a pleasant  experience of which  I really wanted  to enjoy.  No tip.
author: Rick S.

description: They have a really good selection of wines here and the prices are also reasonable, shocking considering the location in the Ferry Building! I live within walking distance, and I like to come here to pick up wine for parties and for hostess gifts. I like how they have a huge selection of roses front and center as you walk in (with many bottles in the $18-22 range). The one thing I absolutely depend on them for is this fantastic rose champagne from France that I have not seen anywhere else. It's an incredible value and I won't tell you what it is because I don't want them to be sold out of it all the time! The employees are really nice. They hit that sweet spot between giving help when needed (including digging out the very last bottle of rose champagne) and leaving you alone when you just want to browse. They're also very knowledgeable. This is a great neighborhood wine shop masquerading as a tourist spot. The only complaint I have is the price of their Veuve Cliquot. Sometimes you just need to buy Veuve and because it's such a popular brand and product, you know what the pricing is at big chains like Costco and Trader Joe's. If Ferry Plaza Wine Merchant could lower their price on Veuve to a bit closer to other stores, I'd happily buy it there for the convenience.
author: Cat M.

description: I love this place. I make sure I come here every time I visit. GREAT wine and I love the food too.
author: Brian M.

description:
Took out of town friends here for a bite and a sip or three, and they loved it.

What's not to like, the welcome is warm, the menu has lots of nice snacks, and the wines on offer are great, such selection.

We had wine flights and there were amazing, like a trip around the world, and paired with the cheese plates...superb!

Great place, come check it out.

Enjoy!
author: William M.

description: AMAZING! My office uses them every time we order for an event. Bo is absolutely incredible and so responsive. THE BEST customer service I have ever received at a beverage retailer. Also, they will place special orders.
author: Marceline K.

description:
My coworkers and I had a lot of fun hanging out in SF for the day, and our last stop was here.

We took over the entire bar and a table, but there was still other seating available for other patrons, so it's not like we took over the whole place, but it's not exactly a full blow restaurant size.  It's a shop within the Ferry Building.

There is a good selection of wines (or so I'm told since I don't drink - I had a great Pelligrino blood orange soda in a wine glass thank you very much) and their little menu of food items - remember this is a WINE BAR - was great to go with the wine and do a little snacking. Most of the items on the menu are locally sourced, and I really mean locally - cheese is from Cowgirl Creamery and the bread is from Acme Bread, both of which is in the Ferry Building as well (which by the way whatever we order was beyond fabulous....I wish I lived closer....next time with a cooler and i'm not flying I'll have to buy some fabulous cheese and bread)

Unfortunately even though we are in the Ferry Building, most of the stores do not have windows, so it can be rather dark on the inside, but if you are closer to the main walkway in building - basically the store front, it is quite bright since there is the huge skylight all the way up and down the building.

Prices weren't too bad, but I can see how if they are filled with patrons, you wont have a place to sit.  You might need to hover.
author: Grace C.

description: Great place to sit back and wind down.  My day at the Pier is always perfect after this place.  There are delicious cheese and meat platters.  I can't get enough of it here!
author: Julie C.

description: I like this place. A little pricey for a beer but the craft selection (which is all they have) is awesome. I got the Ballast Point IPA...not to hoppy, really good. The setting was nice and there's other artisan shops in the building from wines to cheeses, to salted pig parts...I think that's the actual name of the place, lol. If you're catching the ferry from San Francisco check this place out and I'm sure you can find something you love. Bring some dough though.
author: Sergio L.

description:
Every time we're in the Ferry Building, we stop in here for a glass or two.  If you sit in the "outside" area (it's still technically indoors, but a kind of patio at the same time) you will be guaranteed some pretty awesome people-watching.  If you sit indoors, the atmosphere is calm and nice and classy, just the way a wine bar should be.

The by-the-glass menu is pretty good and there's a little something for everyone.  You can also order beer if you're feeling not so winey.  

Cheese plates are excellent here.  The portions are more than generous for one thing -- you'll probably never get this much cheese at another wine bar for the same price.  Bonus points for the use of Cowgirl Creamery and Acme Bread stuff.  Yum!  Oh man, and you have to try the peach chutney.  So good I could stuff it right in my butt.  Marinated mushrooms & olives mix?  Okay.  I'm fat now, thanks a lot.

Service can sometimes seem a little snooty....not at all rude, but I've kind of gotten that icy vibe a little bit.  Not only from the server, but also from the guy at the counter in the retail area.  Oh well, I can't really blame them -- putting up with droves of tourists all day would kind of take the enthusiasm out of my sails too I bet.

The little wine shop attached to the bar is well organized and stocked with a nice range of wines.  They're sorted by region for the most part (you will find me drooling in the Germany section every time), plus bubblies on the left hand side of the room and even a caviar selection at the back.  Nice for browsing during an afternoon shopping at the Ferry Building!

Oh!  One other thing -- you can sign up for classes through their website (www.fbwm.com) -- taught by master sommaliers.  I think we're gonna do the wine & food pairing and the Riesling classes this year.  Eee!  If we do, I'll update my review accordingly!
author: Heather K.

description:
Spent roughly one hundred dollars in this place and received one of the worst customer service experiences -ever!.  I've been in the wine and hospitality trade since living in Napa for 26 years and these "experts" need to get it together.

No. 1 - stood at the tasting bar waiting for some eye contact to happen with the gentleman behind the bar that was consumed with the perfect buffered wine glass.  After several minutes he finally looked up and I asked him about how the tasting worked and he wasn't helpful at all.  I felt I was intruding on his buffering time.  He's got that classic "clueless look" down!  I decided to purchase a glass of bubbles and a glass of chardonnay for my coworker and I that ended up costing $41.53 including tip for that matter!

No. 2 - while enjoying the wine we decided to look for the wines that we had at our luncheon which were amazing.  The store is confusing with their signage and further more I stood with that classic "clueless look" and no one approached me to see if I needed any help.  ...and I clearly needed help.   So I there I stood in the middle of the shop seeing at least 5 employees that were wearing logo zip vests, two were in a  conversation near me in front of the refrigerated champagne selections, another talking with a friend.  So I walked around and saw the white wine that we had a lunch - surprised to find it I was feeling better that I helped myself.  I couldn't figure out where the Spanish Reds were located so finally my coworker asked a employee if we could have some help.  She said,  "of course and that there were several employees that could help us" as she directed us to the Spanish Reds.  I asked for a RIOJA and I guess I pronounced it slightly incorrectly and she immediately corrected my pronunciation in front of everyone -  which made me feel even better about myself and added to my disappointment of this terrible customer service experience.  Hello! you either want to move wine or you just want to walk around looking busy and act the part of a wine professional.  

Here's my suggestion, take a customer service class, move to wine country, like what you do, but don't try to correct a interested customer about wine, it comes off as an insult (oh wait maybe you're charging for that experience too).

So in closing I found the RIOJA (re-o-hah by the way)...$42, the Spanish White $28 - I asked if they offered a wine industry discount and they said no.  Which is another disappointing policy, here's why..."they" will want to go visit a winery one of these days somewhere and "they" will expect a wine industry discount (30%!) and "they" will get it.  So you might want to think about changing your policy because people who work at a winery refer people to fine retail wine shops all the time!

here's the clincher.....I still bought wine!
What did this whole customer service disaster cost me?  $117.76

In vino veritas!
author: Sasha P.

description:
Good wine selection, overpriced bar food.
My major gripe is that they show prices for wine by the glass in ounces,, but show carafe price by the milliliter make it difficult to compare value, had get the conversion on my phone - rude and deceptive.
author: Stewart B.

description: We were not able to get into the most famous oyster bar on the pier before heading to the airport so we went here for a bite to eat.  The wine selection was extensive and we got a sample before ordering.  The crab cakes were perfect with the wine that was recommended.  The atmosphere was that of an urban wine bar mixed with cheese shop, glass and metal appointments, an energy in the room that was just right for a Sunday late afternoon, relaxed but trendy-in a good way.  Wine bottles all around that made us want to take home a mixed case, but alas we were flying.  Would definitely go there again if in SF even though we seldom repeat in a town where we visit and we are exploring.
author: Marcie S.

description:
Stopped by the Ferry Plaza Wine Merchant to purchase wine for a book signing event at Book Passage in the Ferry Building, and asked for three bottles of "not-too-pricey" wine.  When I was presented with three bottles @ $18 each, I asked the sales person if there was something less expensive and was told in a condescending tone that I should not have asked for his recommendation, and that i should have "shopped at Safeway."
Is that any way to speak to a customer? 

Troubled by this, I wrote a polite letter to the store manager and still have not received any response--or apology.
author: Alice S.

description:
Great place to unwind after a long day... It definitely was for us. My friends had some wine and a local IPA. We ordered a Boccalone salumi platter that's on the Ferry Plaza Wine Merchant's menu. It came with capocollo, prosciutto, soppressata, olives and cheese. We enjoyed that... They encourage their customers to bring back goods from the other businesses in the Ferry Building to have with their wine... I dig that. In fact, they give complimentary bread from the Acme Bread Company down the way.

Our waiter was really cool. He was patient with us and attentive enough but not bugging. He had some good suggestions and my friends were pretty receptive to them. We brought food from Boccalone and Cowgirl Creamery cheese. It was a good few hours spent. They have tables that accommodate 4 to 8 people. We were on a high table for 4 and it was just right for our group. The bar seems to gets pretty packed with the after-work crowd. Looked like they offered tastings... Overall, we had a really good experience here. I highly recommend it.
author: Chuck D.

description: Great place to stop for a good to great wine at a decent price (for San Francisco). Fun to people-watch here, too. And, every now and then a tourist will come in and you can kill an hour or more giving them tips on what to do and see here. The store section has a great selection and the staff are the best - friendly, efficient, and they know their wines. The wines by the glass list changes every Wednesday, so if you were in there last week, go back in this week for something new!
author: Steve K.

description:
One of my favorite weekend drinking events: bottles of wine at Wine Merchant, paired with carboloading Acme Bread and upsetting my lactose intolerance with Cowgirl Creamery cheeses.  

I spend hours here on Saturdays.  First come first serve seating. I'd recommend to sit at the bar since the service isn't all that amazing.
author: Katie C.

description: This place sucked. $36.00 for a tasting. The guy working the wine bar was not attentive until we paid the bill. Don't waste your time with this tourist trap.
author: Robert D.

description:
Sat at the bar by myself on an afternoon of aimless wandering through the city, and had an amazing time. Lured in by a white cotes du Rhone by the glass listed on the menu outside, the bartender apologized that they had just changed the menu and had replaced it with a Macon chardonnay. Would I like that instead? Sure, a nice crisp white Burg sounded fine. Not what I was looking for, but it would do. 

That's when it started. Digging in to the menu, I realized I was in a by the glass wine geek's paradise. A Coravined wine section? Yes, please. I finished the refreshing Macon and asked for a glass of the '12 Didier Dagueneau Silex sauv blanc. Knowing full well it needed a moment to wake up, I sipped a tasty German riesling in the meantime. During my interlude,  the bartender (Jason I think? Bad with names) found what was left of the white Rhone I was looking for initially and poured me a couple ounces. Nice touch, and much appreciated.

Hungry now, and wanting food to go with the Silex, I almost ordered the first cheese plate that struck me, but Jason steered me towards a massive hunk of Vermont goat cheese that paired perfectly with the incredibly intense, funky sauv blanc. And I'll be damned if that wine wasn't everything I wanted it to be. At $35 a glass, it's certainly not a bargain, but totally worth it for a wine that I've been wanting to try but not drop the 120ish for a bottle. It was an hour and a half of sheer bliss. Thanks Wine Merchant!
author: Ian B.

description:
I'm sure this is a good place to get wine, but I hate wine.

As far as beer is concerned, this place is good too. They have a large selection of bottles and don't charge to open bottles on the bar. The draft list was so-so so be sure to check out the bottles. A few rarities and the standard "microbrew" beer too.

The food is good and very affordable. Wine Merchant offers smaller portions focused on cheese and meat. Not too bad - the waiter can also pair it with beer if you feel so inclined.

Even though this is focused on being a wine place, the beer here is good too.
author: Justin A.

description:
A bit confused on the negative ratings RE: service.  After engaging the servers a bit during a very busy Saturday lunch recently, we had a very good experience.

We found the servers to be very nice, accommodating and eager to please despite having to tend to patrons three deep to the bar.

We started with two of the special tastings available; a Chardonnay and a Rose Sparkling Wine.  After that, we perused the store and found one of our favorite Pinot Noir (Flowers!) and had that opened for us to enjoy with our Salumi and Cheese platters; excellent.

We then asked for a suggestion on another Pinot Noir (Hey, we were on vacation!) and we were directed by Jason to a PERFECT Pinot!

After that, the stragglers in our party showed up and we were able to move seats around and enjoy individual selections. Jason set out a few Petite Syrah to try, two of which were quite good.

All-in-all, it was a great way to spend an early afternoon enjoying great wine, friends, food and people-watching. We look forward to doing this again some time.
author: Albert Y.

description: Sadly, after trying to visit this place since the day they opened I have given up on it completely. I am a native San Franciscan and always seem to get excellent service most places that I go. For some reason, every time I visit this place I have the impression that the bartender absolutely despises me. They always ignore me when I sit down and take forever to say hello even though they are standing right in front of me. Then when they finally do stop to ask me what I would like to order they seem to have complete distain for me as though I had poisoned their pet poodle in some previous lifetime. Once again, I ordered a glass of wine and it seems that they found some ancient bottle that had been open for about a month and turned to vinegar. The wine they served me was hideous for that reason. As usual, I did not drink the wine that I ordered, paid my bill and left a standard tip. All very expensive following the standard SF model. It may be that I remind the bartender of someone that he hates. I have no idea, but I will never waste any more of my time or money in that place again. They don't want me there, and I finally got the message. Sadly, I have the impression that they don't like women at all, and I really hope that is not the case and it is just me personally that they despise.
author: Anonanon S.

description:
First come first serve with seats.

Decided to be fancy for the day and all four of us got wine flights which could barely fit on the table. lol. and then we decided to be fancy as fuhhh and get caviar as well. delishh. 

It was nice to sit and rest after pigging out and walking around SF and the ferry building. Got pretty buzzed hehehe and whipped out the cheese I bought from Cowgirl Creamery next door earlier. #noshame

Service was not fast not slow. It was pretty busy so its understandable. They had a TV to watch sports and a bar you can just stand around as well.
author: Rachel C.

description:
The retail staff is excellent, but the experience with the staff behind the bar today was disgusting. We went in today about 15 mins before they closed (which was 5pm on Sunday). While someone in retail was helping my friend choose a wine, I walked up to the counter with a beer in my hand with the sole purpose of just asking the bartender if she could throw it away for me since there was no trashcan around. She was bending down behind the counter and said something to me, which I did not understand seeing as how she did not even have the decency to stop what she was doing to address a possible customer. I said, "I'm sorry what?" And she replied by saying that if I wanted to purchase something it needed to be done at the retail counter, which I already well knew. And I said oh no, I was just wondering if you can take this piece of trash. And she said yeah just set it on the counter so I did and walked away. As I walked away, she said "there's no need for an attitude, I just saw you walk up with a beer". I didn't bother to turn around to get her name or ask her to repeat herself, as it was the end of my day and I'm sure the end of hers as well.  

That type of response is unacceptable to a customer or a human being,  seeing as how I was not rude to her in slightest bit, and I certainly don't need to explain my natural demeanor to someone who's only job is to give someone decent service.  

We are regulars at this shop, but thanks to the woman working the closing shift at the bar this Sunday, you will never have our money again.
author: Alana W.

description: Impressive wine bar. Love how it's convieniently located in the historic ferry building. You can do some shopping & then wind down at this amazing wine bar. This place was hopping. We sat right at the bar & were helped right away. Although busy we were never forgotten. I loved how you can mix & match your pours from 2oz-5oz pours. Prices were extremely reasonable considering we ordered French wines by the glass. Our favorites were the Gros Nore Bandol & Lanson black label. We bought a bottle of the pink Lanson to take home. Great place to catch up with friends or wind down after work.
author: Mary A.

description:
Love this place! They have a great selection of wines and the staff is always very helpful. You can do flight tastings or create your own tasting with 2oz tastings of any of their wines by the glass. 
They also have yummy snacks, I love the Cow Girl Creamery Mt. Tam cheese and bread!
author: Nicole M.

description: I absolutely love this place!  I am a huge fan of wine and cheese and this is just the perfect spot, whether you're with family, a boyfriend or friend.  What I also appreciate is the number of seats at the bar and surrounding tables that this place can accommodate given how most other spots in the Ferry Building are small and/or do not have seats (just stands).  Love this spot and it is a must-try anytime in SF.
author: Liza V.

description:
I love this place. The staff is so accommodating and unpretentious here. I started with a 2oz taste of the Ferry Plaza Wine Merchant Pinot Noir, only to love it so much, the server added 3oz and charged me the price of the 5oz glass instead of two 2oz tastes. They allow you to eat your foods purchased from other shops in the Ferry Building, as long as you practice consideration and clean up after yourself. My husband enjoyed his La Fin Du Monde beer(s) immensely. Okay, maybe a little too immensely. 

Go to Ferry Plaza Wine Merchant to sit, relax, people watch and mull over your life dilemmas!
author: KJ N.

description:
My friend and I felt discriminated by a waiter at this bar.

He made us wait to get a table unnecessarily, ignored us multiple times, passing us by when I raised my hand like "excuse me", which I think anyone could notice we need him to come over our table.

I don't know his name but he was young, tall, caucasian, having light brown hair, and wearing a burgundy polo shirt.

Another waiter who took care of us was nice at least. 
We were there between 5 to 7pm on Friday, May 27.

Wine and snacks were fine but I don't know if I will come back to this bar.
author: Em T.

description: I really wanted to give a higher rating here. This place could have a friendlier waiter staff. I don't recall his name but he was a bit elder with glasses. If I have questions about the menu don't be a douche bag about it. Also the waiter kept running away after each order I tried to make and was overall just an awkward person. Who's idea was it to make him the face of customer service?
author: Shen D.

description: On a Friday night, get here at like 3pm to get a table and beat out the tourists and the rest of us deadbeats who snuck out of work early, (except me Boss!  I've been at work since 6AM! said the girl scout).  Then order that platter of gruyere and olive prosciutto tapenade and a little loaf of Acme bread while polishing it off with a bottle of Syrah and Pinot. Spend $170 and watch the other scouts who couldn't quite get out of work earlier than 5 ogle your table.
author: Joc V.

description:
Hard not to love the Ferry Building generally, but this wine shop/wine bar adds a lot to the small business community housed there. Staff is friendly and helpful and they have a good selection of wine from around the world for purchase. 

I've also been in a few times for to sit down at their wine bar to sample their wines and nibble on their various snacks. Their menu has a number of food items from other Ferry Building shops (Cowgirl Creamery, Acme Bread, etc), which is really cool. My only complaint is that the space feels a little boxed in since there is no natural light (windows, etc). Still after a glass of wine and some delicious cheese you don't really notice.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
The good: great location for an after-work drink, good wine and beer selection, knowledgeable staff in the store portion, helpful waitstaff at the bar, and a good selection of affordable wines for purchase.

The bad: gets super crowded on Friday evenings, limited selection of cheeses and charcuterie, and the older waiter that services the back tables is not nice or helpful or particularly conscientious.
author: Anonymous F.

description: Hubs and I were in search of a Californian wine to drink with our pier picnic. We really liked the service at the Ferry Plaza Wine Merchant. Service aside, we were disappointed that they didn't have a larger selection of Californian wines. We also felt that the price range was on the higher end and that they didn't offer a large selection if value-priced wines. All in all, it is a nice shop and was great in a pinch, but if time permitted I would probably shop elsewhere.
author: Lisa S.

description:
It's an ongoing tradition since the end of last year to come up to SF and spend the entire day in the city but mostly at the Ferry Building. One may not think you can spend more than 5 hours in the Building but I got this down. 
I always end up stopping here and hanging out for a nice glass of wine (and some Champs). I prefer to sit at the bar and just relax for a few hours; one of the better bartenders (I know I am messing up your name but I believe its Cyrus or something close to that) is perfect with just being there enough to know when to fill our glass but not being pushy in anyway. He is very knowledgeable about the wine selection and making excellent recommendations to try to expand our palate. 
I have had a time or two when I sat at a table because of no seats at the bar and received sub-par almost rude service but honestly, the other bartender makes up for it when we can grab a seat.
author: Kelly T.

description:
I love this place! Glen couldn't be more fun or provide better service! Even without the amazing wine selection (from all around the world- natch!) I'd come just for the service. And let's talk about the cheese. Yummmmm! 
Hiii Glennnn! Can't wait to see you again! Get ready with the scrumptious bubbles ;)
author: Ali W.

description:
Nice wine selection. I had a nice Bordeaux for $9 and my friend had a sweet Sauterne for $6. 

The bar menu and accompaniments are perfect and fairly priced. 

The people watching is as good as in any airport.
author: Chris S.

description:
Store side: 
Great selection, knowledgeable staff, and some fantastic under $20 picks. Truly awesome wine club - if you're local and can pick-up instead of paying for shipping I highly recommend joining. 

Bar side: 
Service is prompt but unfriendly. No guidance on selection although I was explaining my preferences and asking - instead I was told "they are all good".  No smiles or even eye contact throughout our rounds. Wine prices are decent, especially considering location. The food pricing seems on the high side so I recommend snacking throughout the ferry building instead. 

TL;DR: high five on store, skip the bar 

DFTBA ~ chase
author: Chase S.

description: Thumbs up for the variety of wines served at the wine bar, but thumbs down for their appetizers being served in the plastic containers they came in...it would have seemed a lot more "homemade" if the artichoke dip we got had just been scooped into a bowl!
author: Hayley H.

description:
This is a great place to people watch in the ferry building. You aren't going to get much guidance on wine choice so read up beforehand because a wrong choice will cost you $$. All in all the cheese selection was fab and you can get everything your order from the local merchants right next door. 

Faves: cowgirl creamery mt tam cheese
author: Christina L.

description: I LOVE this spot. I am slowly becoming a regular. There's no view and it can be tough to find a seat but it's one of my favorite after work places. They offer a great selection of wines by the taste, glass and bottle and change the list often.  They also have amazing meat and cheese plates from the local stores right there in the Ferry Building, all served with local Acme bread, of course. Sometimes, after a long day at work, there's nothing like splitting a bottle of wine with a girlfriend and mowing down on Cowgirl Creamery cheese and bread!
author: Hannah C. R.

description: Awesome location in the Ferry Building.  Get a seat while you can.  I like the wine flights from all over the world (not just Cali) to taste a variety.   The Brie and manchego cheese plate is plentiful with baguette, olives and mushrooms.  Service is slow bit friendly .... Who cares when you're enjoying wine.  Nice mix of retro music playing.  Closes around 8 - last call.
author: Alli M.

description:
This is one of those places where you wonder if it will be so touristy it will have crappy wines. It won't. This place has an amazing selection of wines and extremely knowledgeable staff.

They have a massive selection of wine. They also have a great to amazing selection of cheeses and appetizer plates.

It's great for coming here as a group or as an individual.

I just wished they showed something other than golf on the TVs. Any sport would be fine. Or whatever. But both of the 2 TVs showing golf is a bit much. iMHO. No stars down in case that's who they are drawing in.... But PLEASE note because I doubt it is.

Also nice, coming as a sole female feels very comfortable. If you are female and go out on your own, you know what I mean. You want to try wine, are okay with a nice crowd and/or bartender, but don't want any risk of being harassed.

They have great deals for members too. Serious steals.
author: Zoe D.

description: Again for me it's all about customer service. Sunday 4pm. Place was fairly empty, ask server how does it work here? So we buy the wine or is there bar service?  Condescendly, she states "like any other bar" hmmm not the answer we were looking for!   Very disappointing, the attitude just left a bad taste in my mouth.  The server that finally came to our table was fine, not great service but just the basics.. I guess as  a local we are not welcomed and this is a tourist trap. Too bad since the wine selection seemed quite good.  They need to address the condescending female working the bar on Sunday the 8th of October. Get a clue your in customer service.  Learn what that means.
author: Mel M.

description:
They have a nice variety of wines, both from a price and geographic perspective.  The associates are knowledgeable, and willing to assist without that wine snob mentality.  

I've also hosted a couple of events here, and Silas made it a rock star memorable evening for my guests. 

Be sure to check out the wines under $15, I believe, by the entrance....some gems in those crates, for sure.  It happens to be across the street from my office, so that helps, but it doesn't influence my review.  A must visit, if you're in the Ferry Bldg.  :)

Cheers!
author: Michael J.

description:
Took a break after the last meeting and before dinner to relax here with colleagues. I had 3hours to kill and thought, I'm on a business trip, and can relax and have a drink before 5p.m. as I usually can't when I'm back home.

Ordered a beer as usual from a local brand and a wine that the store makes on it's own. Not much of a wine drinker but do like chardonnay. Got a tasting of the  original chardonnay that they make here and quite honest, it was very smooth and good. If I didn't have to drive, would've ordered another one.

Shame that I've forgotten the name of it but will ask the waiter the next time I return. They even allowed outside drinks and food.
author: Reo T.

description:
Set in one of the most popular places of San Francisco, aka the Ferry building, you really need to try out this place. The most intriguing part about most of the stores in the marketplace is probably the micro-economy that's going on here. This place makes no exception: the bread comes straight from Acme bread while Cowgirl provides cheese that flawlessly matches the wines served here.

I'm not a big fan of Californian wines, but thanks to the FP Wine merchant, I've now discovered a few bottles that caught my attention. My tip would be to take a flight of wines, which entitles you to either 3 or 4 glasses of wine, depending on your preference on reds or whites, and to combine it with a platter of cheese and bread. 

4 stars for the excellent staff and wines served here, yet, believe it or not, no 5 stars since sometimes the staff just likes the wine a little too much...
author: Nicolas S.

description: Nice atmosphere and great food and wine. The selection was perfect, even though it was still hard to choose, so many things looked and sounded good. All the cheese, meat, and bread are sourced from the other local merchants in the Ferry building, and that is great! I wanted to give five stars, but didn't because our server was a bit gruff with his attitude, but have to say, he did recommend a great bottle of wine, that I regret not purchasing.
author: Rachelle Z.

description: Walking through the Ferry Build... wife and I wanted a glass of wine and say this place with a good amount of people there... got a seat, looked at the wine list and then decided to get a bottle of wine with fresh cheese, bread, and olive tepanade.... what a fun way to kill a couple of hours... drinking good wine (and the mark-up was only 11 bucks higher than the bottle price), really good food, and service was really nice.
author: Mark K.

description: The wine is good. I hate to even give this review. BUT. Our bartender was SO COLD to us after I told her I didn't like my wine and asked for something different(which was more expensive than the first). It was super rude. And just to preference we drank a couple glasses before this, so I'm not just being a choosy bitch. Which I am. But my advice is to know EXACTLY what you want, or else you will be greeted w evil eyes.
author: Jasmine S.

description:
Great wine and beer selection, and the small plate of fresh cheese from Cowgirl Creamery just next door, along with a fresh small loaf of fresh bread, baked in the Ferry Building can't be beat for $7.50. I love stopping here on my way into the city via ferry. I bring a book, sit at the bar, enjoy the sights and sounds of the Ferry Building as I relax with a glass of wine.

Extensive wine collection on sight with wine club membership, too. Many different events held year-round.

Don't miss! Cheers!
author: Lisa L.

description: Love, love, love this place. Friendly staff will help you select a wine and recommend better wines than you though you wanted.  Wonderful cheese and cured meat plates are the perfect afternoon degustation with one of the many wonderful wines.  A must do place in SF.  Be prepared for  short wait to score a table. Trust me it's worth the wait.  And the tables toward the back are all good so take one of those and feel like you are sitting in your own cellar on the bay.
author: Robert A.

description: I don't find myself in the ferry building often, but when I do, the wine merchant makes a perfect stop for some drinks and some nosh.  All of the wines I've tried here have  been delightful.  While the prices may be a little higher than your neighborhood wine bar, the selection is very well curated.  The food menu includes a number of excellent cheeses, including some local options, complemented by Acme bread. On my most recent visit, I tried the pate plate, which was divine.
