I wish I could have managed to eat it all myself.  The staff is friendly and helpful with recommendations with the exception of one male server who acts like he is very put out to have to wait on customers.
author: Heidi M.

description:
Stars off the charts, both for the wine, the food, and the company.

When meeting dear friends of one's seven star companion, it always helps when they turn out to be People Like Me. This was determined within about 4 seconds of meeting two new people outside SF's Ferry Plaza Building. The phrase "We can just go to the wine bar in here and hang out" instantly made me think I was in the presence of like-minded descamisados. 

And I was. 

Swilling champagne with unabashed glee, devouring delicious cheese, and the aforementioned spreadable salami (see Boccalone) and dishing the morning away. 

Yes, morning . . . with salami and champagne, is there a problem? I do not see one. Salami, cheese and champagne is a perfectly appropriate breakfast. Don't judge.

If I lived in San Fran (and if you don't stop judging me about the goddamnded morning champagne I am going to move there just to spite you) I'd be spending all my money on the delicious wine here. And hanging out here in weekend mornings eating . . . breakfast (Enough. I don't care what you think).

A li'l price check revealed prices that are not too bad. A variety of DiBon that is much loved sells here for $10 a bottle. Compared to Chicago Binny's it's $7.99, or $14 at Kafka! So, affordable.
author: Erika G.

description:
We're going sailing on our vacation, so of course we'll throw ourselves a bon voyage party!  

What better place than at the Wine Merchant?  They have bread and cheese, the most amazing marinated olives, spiced hot nuts, and, of course, wine!  

You can have a glass of almost anything for under $10, and if you get into a tasting game with the bartender, well, anything can happen.  If you end up tasting 4 different wines, and complement them with an Italian meat plate, you can walk away for just $45 + tip!  

Bon voyage, indeed.
author: David D.

description: Always a great place to meet friends or wait for the next ferry. Quick service, wine list changes regularly, service is hurried but accurate. Even though it is a fast paced place... you can still sit back and relax.
author: Jim H.

description:
Grab a table by the main hallway and you will have one of the best people watching spots in San Francisco.  Come here mainly if you like wine.  It's perfectly OK to bring food from one of the many awesome food places elsewhere in the Ferry building and order their wine at the bar or a table.  But if your idea of a great meal is wine paired with great cheese and maybe some fine meats, then look no further than their own menu, most of which comes from their neighbors in the ferry building anyway.

Wednesday nights are wine maker nights and you can meet local wine experts - a great day to hang out and talk wine with people in the know.  You can talk about the smell of damp earth, or a taste of chocolate and berry, or whatever it is you think you perceive in the wine.
author: David L.

description:
Um, Cowgirl Creamery much? Yes!!!!!

Ginger beer. Goat Cheese. Sweet Baguette. Lemon Hummus. 

I had a low key yet incredible time with an old high school friend recently and hit this marvelous place up. So glad I did. Although I don't drink alcohol (I'm a light weight and WILL throw up on you if I do), the ginger beer was recommended to me and it was spicier than I imagined but smooth nonetheless. $90 bucks for sample wines and the items listed above. Worth every penny.

2 days later I walked away with just about $200 worth of cheese. What can I say? I'm a gourmet cheese whore. So to all the cheese fiends, look no further. mkay?
author: Meghan W.

description: Stopped in to drink some wine and munch on empanadas from across the hall. They have quite an array of wine. I asked for a fruity red wine that wasn't too dry. Server suggested a Syrah that was mild, not too flavorful, but quite expensive. I've had better, which I think was more the server up-selling me than anything.
author: Corey L.

description:
Two stars because the yelp explanation is perfect "Meh, I've experienced better."

Reviews on terrible service are right on. We didn't sit at the bar but grabbed an open table. The server was unfriendy, barely acknowledged us and smirked at our questions. I'm not sure why we didn't just leave. It was Saturday, the server was probably annoyed with the tourists, so whatever. 
I got to a lot of wine bars and this was by far my worst experience. The cheese plates seemed a little pricey but I sure I noticed people brought it their own from cowgirl creamery. Good choice!
My sister and I shared a carafe of the tempranillo and it was just ok. 
The bartenders behind the bar seemed a bit friendlier so maybe that is the place to sit!
Would probably not make it a point to return here.
author: Lisa S.

description: We stumbled on this little place while exploring the Ferry Plaza and decided to give it a try.  Great service, excellent bottle of wine for a very reasonable price. The Boccalone Salumi plate was excellent and while the Oxbow Cheese plate with two rolls was a bit on the small side (four bite-size pieces of chees for $12) they were wonderful bits.  The Coupole Goat cheese was so fantastic and we had to have an order of that all by itself.  Our server was terrific, friendly and accommodating.  The whole order was a meal in itself and cost a lot less than we have spent for other 'meals' during our stay in SF.  Definitely worth the money and so far this has been the highlight of our trip.
author: Penny P.

description: Had a great time here people watching enjoying a meat and cheese platter, sipping wine.  Very extensive wine selection, as you might imagine.    Our server was helpful and we did not feel rushed or hurried.  We did not go on a weekend though, so I can see how the weekend dynamics could change the more casual feel.
author: Deb T.

description: The selection of top shelf such as Opus One, Silver Oak, etc are nationally competitive like with Wine.Com.  Of course you do have to pay tax but no shipping.   We enjoyed some rare local Pinot and Merlot from small estate batches that never reach national shipping and the Terroir was plain and clear due to obvious care in storage and final corking.    Quite nice.
author: Greg D.

description:
What a cool place to hang out on a Saturday at the Ferry Plaza.  The atmosphere is lively, and the crowd is hip and happening...Oh, and the wine selection is pretty good too.

After trying to squeeze in to the fully packed tasting room, I found a small spot at the bar to park myself and order a nice glass of champagne to start my 2 hour wine tasting adventure.  One of the best parts of this tasting room is the people watching - everyone is excited, happy, thirsty, and fun to be around.  The staff was friendly, helpful and fairly quick to take care of you (considering the place was packed).  

After my first champagne round, I ordered a Burrata cheese plate to go with my red wine that was next on my list.  The cheese was so good, and the wine was yummy too.  I am intentionally not listing the names of the wine or champagne so that you can just show up and try anything.  There are so many wines to choose from, just try 3 or 4 and you're sure to find something you like.

I highly recommend hanging out here during the farmers market excitement.
author: Daniel A.

description: Friday 715 pm.  Bar tender is a d o u c h e.  End of story.  Highly recommend the place if you like A holes.
author: Eff z.

description:
Moderately priced.  Especially for the Ferry Buildling!

Great pit stop in the middle of touristy activities.
author: Steven F.

description:
I love coming to the Ferry Building when I am in SF.  Recently my boyfriend and I have been trying new wines and took the recommendation of the lady that worked there. There is also a wine bar there. 

I like this place because they have selection that highlight what good wines are worth trying. 

We are excited to try theses out at our next wine and cheese night. 

The parking around here is not so great, we always try to find street parking.
author: Sheila K.

description: Wine and food are decent at this place.  The service is not.  Last night it took me 3 times to get 2 wine glasses from one of the servers.  And the last time I was there a few weeks ago, the service was similarly, slow and unfriendly.  This place needs to hire professional staff.
author: Scott M.

description:
Did you know that Catherine Keener works here? She sure does, I am convinced of it.

This is more of just a wine shop that sells hard to find bottles of juice. You can actually taste and sample some of the best vinos that our planet has to offer.

Everything from small production to that hard to find late harvest reisling, Wine Merchant is the perfect place to score that perfect bottle that will be sure to impress.
author: V B.

description:
As an experienced bartender, knowledgeable oenophile and someone who worked in a highly respected Bay Area wine shop, I expected better service from this Ferry Building icon. On three occasions I have entered the retail shop to browse the selection but did I ever receive a "Let me know if I can help you find something" from the staff who always were busy talking amongst themselves? No. 
Wine is the embodiment of pleasure and fun in a glass. If the staff cannot convey those feelings in their work maybe they should go back to working at a place with water cooler office gossip where they won't be bothered by pesky customers.
author: Randy C.

description:
Great wine shop with friendly staff. A bit expensive compared with other wine shops in the area but they do carry some hard to find wines.

Top Dine Top Tip: There is a "hidden" list of wines that the shop is not allowed to advertise. I'm sure if one were to ask for particular wineries or bottles by name, a surprisingly wide selection might magically appear...
author: Carlos V.

description: Yes, it's touristy, but I highly recommend!  The wine flights are great and the cheeses are delicious!  Cheers!
author: Candace B.

description:
Eh.   2.5 stars maybe.

Decent selection of wines to purchase and the $6 corkage fee (if I read that correctly) at the bar is outstanding....but I was not all that impressed with the choices at the wine bar itself, with the exception of a Pierre Moncuit sparkler from Le Mesnil-sur-Oger.   

They have a small selection of snacks available, including cheeses, chocolates and salumi from local vendors which is convenient if you're planning on wandering around further and you want to "try before you buy".  Tables are few, and the bar itself is small so this could be a problem during busy times.  It was not.. on the Tuesday afternoon that I was visiting. 

What really knocked points off was the service.  I won't say your name because I don't want to embarrass you here... but here's a tip, girl...  why don't you check to make sure all the customers are taken care of first before you start chatting with your coworker about how your Valentines day dude gave you the run around and then texted you at the last minute about dinner.

I understand about boys and gossip and what not, sister.  I do.  But first things first.  If I have to listen to your drama, at least make sure I have a drink in my hand for Christ sake. 

Also, it would behoove you to perhaps talk more about the wine... you know... *engage* people...  find out their likes and dislikes... that's how you SELL...    at least that's how you sell to people who aren't your friend... who you're happily chatting up about what she should try next...    and who happens to be sitting next to the irritated Yelper that you're ignoring.  

Just a suggestion. 

So, while I hope you all have a better experience than I did... YMMV.  Good luck!
author: Shanna K.

description:
Okay, petty complaining first:
People pack into the wine bar section like sardines, which makes for a lot of bumped elbows and almost spills. With so many people, the staff isn't as attentive as I'd like.

Okay, complaining done. How can you not like a wine bar in a busy market where you can try flights and cheaper tastes? I think we tried six different wines in the span of an hour. It's a lively scene and if you're lucky enough to be sitting in the "patio", you can watch people scurry around looking for their gourmet groceries.

The wines are solid. The servers are pretty knowledgeable. It's all good. I just want more SPACE!
author: Akash K.

description: Not good service, i ask to get a taste of a wine to possible get the bottle, i was told u have to buy a sample. He mention( bar guy) "we are here to make bussines, not to give free samples... Our prices are affordable. Then i ask for a carafe of the wine that could not taste and he mention i am gonna pour tbe wine in two glasses cause our carafes are warm( coming from dishwasher) or do you want it warm???? your wine....then i order a charcuterie plate wich says 8$$ something on menu and he bring it with some bread( one fifth of a baguette) when we got the bill, they charge 3,50$ for the bread...... I wont ever, ever go back to that place. the one star is cause the place looks nice.....
author: Larry L.

description: Great wine store.  Seating is whoever gets to the table 1st wins and believe me this place packs up about lunch time & in the mid afternoon.  The prices are great.  The bartender dude is friendly and gives good suggestions.  The best part is you don't have to order food on their menu, you can bring food from say, cowgirl creamery, and pair the awesome cheese, Mac & cheese, tomato soup, turkey sandwiches, with the delicious wine here for an overall amazing meal.
author: Michael L.

description:
For Ferry Building options, this is a nice place to sit, relax, enjoy a cheese or charcuterie plate or a glass of wine, and people watch. For that, I like it. 

However, the service is the problem. Numerous reviews here mention the poor service. Unfortunately, on our visit, we definitely experienced it firsthand. Our server was not very friendly and comes across rude and snooty. But he also just seems socially awkward. Anyway, it is enough of a turn off that I would not return unless someone else wanted to come here. I think there are better options in and outside of the Ferry Building.
author: Veronica H.

description:
This place conjures up sweet memories...
Whether it is enjoying a table full of delights from the farmer's market..paired with delicious wines..or or spending a lazy Sunday afternoon sipping on a good Pinot...I always leave with a smile on my face. 
Over the years I've met the nicest people here..and I've received nothing but 1st class service (despite some other negative reviews)
Most recently I came here with someone special and while the place was a bit crowded, Silas managed to find us some bar stools and squeezed us into the end of the bar..where it was nice and cozy..
Anytime I have friends in town..we head to the Ferry Plaza...with the wine merchant on the top of my list...
author: Mimi T.

description: This place has a pretty good selection of wines.  You can even sit there and drink. If you're in a rush, this is a great place to pick up a bottle for a gift.  Finally found a store that sells a neoprene single bottle bag!
author: Erica S.

description: Large selection of wine by the glass available.  Can be hard to get a seat if you are there during commuting hours.
author: Nicki N.

description: Great place to have a glass of wine.  Super selection and knowledge of sparkling wine.
author: Mark G.

description: Great place to sit, relax and people watch. Friendly, knowledgeable bartenders.
author: Alyssa K.

description: Such a shame. Location is amazing and the wine selection in the store is adequate. Unfortunately the selection in the wine bar is pretty poor. You might be able to overlook that but for the service. Staff may or may not be knowledgable but they don't talk enough for you to figure that out. If you pause while ordering they just walk away. I had to ask if I said something wrong to cause him just to leave. He said he just got distracted. Won't be back
author: Fred D.

description: The bartender who works here is dreamy, he looks like jefferson from married with children. Other than that we should be married soonly, the french champs here are good toooo
author: Angela M.

description:
So we bought Acme bread, Cowgirl cheeses, Boccalone meats, and now, we're gonna have a nosh lunch with some wine at the Wine Merchant.  PERFECT!  

We sat down and the gentleman helped us by offering cheese boards and knives.  

We ordered a glass of cab sav and an interesting white wine.  Really delicious wines and the service was so great.  We had a seat on their patio, so we saw a bunch of jealous people staring at our bread, cheese, meats and wine.  they should be jelo because it was SO GOOD!
author: Crystal L.

description: sunny and beautiful sunday afternoon...flight arrival from san diego to sfo...straight to waterbar and champagne brunch completed...a stroll to ferry building for a second round...ferry plaza wine merchant...a great setup and service...buy a bottle and drink it there...market priced wines!...shop, bring and eat all the delectable eatables ferry building has to offer...or, lazy and order samplings from the wine merchant...our group lazy...tables and chairs provided...glasses plenty, wine bottles uncorked and a pour with a smile..great service...pour after pour...bottle after bottle...scrumptious caviar...cowgirl creamery cheeses...acme bread...platter of meat slivers...a moment of happiness experienced...or, was it the three bottles of wine?...bottles had $twenty-five to $forty per...add on the caviar and samplings...a royal snack to bring total to $three-hundred even for four...
author: Hen A.

description: Great selection of wine from around the world. I came to buy precisely Santorini Greek wine. They only had one bottle out. When asked one of the staff, he checked the back and computer system. Found two more in stocked. He checked all over the find two more bottles for me. Great Services... I didn't waste my trip to Ferry Building hauling 3 bottles of wine back at all.
author: Pokemon P.

description: I had the 2012 Cakebread Chardonnay. Never knew 5oz could get ya boy buzzin! haha. This white wine is smooth and I'm glad I chose it. lol. We paired the wine w their sliced Italian meat plate. Let me tell you, flavor gang! The mild coppa is a flavor burst in your mouth. #mouthgasm. Great for a party of 2-4.
author: Ryan Q.

description:
After waiting in line for 20 + minutes for everything else on a Saturday, sometimes you just need a drink.  It's always packed, but if you wait 5-10 minutes, you'll probably get lucky and find a seat.

They have lots of glasses to try in 3 oz or 5 oz options, or you can get the 375ml or 750ml ones.  You could also get a bottle from the store and have them open it for $6 corkage.  

What's wine without some cheese?  They usually have a sampler for $10 to go with the monthly wine flights (1 oz each with part of an acme epi baguette), or if you know what you want, just order it (or get it from Cowgirl next door!  shh...).  The bread there is as fresh as if you get it straight from acme next door.

Definitely take advantage of the wine bar to relax a little after all the stress of waiting in lines, squeezing through crowds, and trying to get a porchetta sandwich before they run out!
author: Marilyn T.

description:
I give 3 stars simply because I can not forgive the service.  My review does not apply to every server there.   I have had good service by servers who seem interested and knowledgeable about wine.  I recently visited and when I saw who the server was I immediately felt regret and knew that he would negatively shape my experience.  I was not disappointed and his lack of personality, care, and total "I hate being a server" attitude became almost humorous to my husband and me.  The icing on the cake was when he poured the white wine from the chiller and the wet bottle dripped all over my lap. 

What he doesn't really seem to understand is that service is more than just delivering food and drink in a timely fashion.  

I love the Wine Merchant for it's wine, location and people watching, but I'm not sure how many more visits I can deal with such curiously bad service.
author: Jay W.

description:
Came here again with my boyfriend. Ordered bottle of wine. 

I don't remember much after that.......so I'll take that as the place rocks and I had a great time...
author: Jackie F.

description: Nice place.  Came here for a quick drink and less than $20 for a flight of 4 wines can do no wrong.  Super nice and accommodating server helps the cause as well.  Will def be back.
author: Ricky C.

description:
I big time heart this place. Awesome place to chill, experiment trying a few new and different kinds of wine, or beer if that's your libation of choice. 

It's basically a wine shop with a wine bar/bistro attached. They feature an extensive wine list by the glass, carafe or by the bottle. You can also order glasses in 2 and 5 oz portions...just in case you're not sure if your 2 oz selection will be swill. Pretty sure they don't serve that here. Seriously had one of the best wines I've tried in a very long time here called Hatcher Cinsault. It's a winery from Murphys, CA in the gold country. Outstanding. 

The wine bar also lets you purchase any selection from their shop and bring it in to enjoy. 

My husband ordered a small cheese plate to snack on. Also got a mini baguette served there but acquired by the wine merchants from the nearby (and pretty famous in bread circles) Acme Bread Co. 

Definitely hit this place! Staff is friendly and helpful. It's a treat within the Ferry Bldg, which is a treat in itself, too!
author: ciara c.

description: Fantastic wines and a nice selection of beers.  But I went alone thinking that I'd chat with a tourist at the bar or someone like myself who is kicking back after work.  I might as well have gone to Starbucks considering that everyone at the bar either had a laptop or a book, and the staff was equally disengaged (unless you count the bartender being sweet to his girlfriend).  It feels corporate and isn't a "friendly" wine bar unless you bring your own friends.
author: Gail S.

description: Great location and the perfect spot to kill time waiting for the ferry (I'm a commuter) but the service is pretty lame.  I witnessed a host veyr loudly tell a lady she could not sit at the bar as there was a waitlist - news to me, I saw plenty of open seats.  If i were here I would not have come back but she did after about 10 min.  Only to sit at the bar, just as I did and barely get acknowledged by the bartender(s).  I love the venue but am NOT a fan of the service and vibe.  Go to Hog Island Oyster Bar instead, they will wait on you hand and foot the minute you sit down.
author: Leslie M.

description:
I need a bottle of wine so I can get drunk.  Or at least get this one guy drunk so we can both make our way through what may or may not be an awkward t.v. watching, pizza eating evening.

Upon considering my options to get said bottle of wine, I vetoed the driving to TJ's after my Bart journey, completely forgot about Rincon Market, and then remembered the wine merchant in the Ferry Building that I always walk by and have never been into.  Based on the reviews, I figured I'd give it a shot.  Since I wanted to quasi-impress my guest, I didn't want a cheapy wine from the under $10 section, I splurged on the under $20 section.  

I was somewhat disappointed in the staff.  I wandered around for a good 15 minutes, and while I think I'm a pretty good judge of wine (as an alcoholic), I still would have liked some assistance.  I'm not really one to ask for help, but I kind of expected someone to offer.  And the guy who rang me up needed to take happy pills.  

I will be back to try their wine and cheese pairings, just as soon as my liver recovers from my last visit.
author: Pam S.

description: Great selection for the size of the place, and the go-to spot for when I need to go to a dinner party after work or bring a gift to a birthday.  they are very helpful and won't steer your wrong.  I'm a fan.
author: Mike V.

description:
Decent price and great selection for their wine bar.  However, the service was seriously lacking.  Maybe because there was only 1 person serving everyone?  Good thing Jane and I were extremely happy after several sips, we didn't really care much about the service.

They have wide price range for wine selection, by the glass, by the mini glass (to try), by half bottle, or by whole bottle.  Great to share a half bottle for 2, or maybe a bottle if you don't have to work after.  I would love to try out their cheese plate (which is from Cow Girl next door.) and they also serve ACME bread.   Cheese, bread, and wine?  Sign me up for that!
author: Gigi T.

description: Great service and selection.
author: Gerald H.

description:
I have walked by this place numerous times when it's empty and when busy. 

After ordering my sandwich from Boccalone next door, I came here for a drink to accompany my sandwich. It was pretty crowded with a mix of people -- couples, groups of people, solos, etc.. 

The service is pretty good. I told the gal what I had and asked to recommend a red wine that would accompany it well. I don't remember the wine I got, but it was very peppery and went well with the muffuletta. 


I enjoy going to a pub or wine bar with a friendly and vibrant atmosphere. Get a drink and chat with the person next to you. Always something to learn.

I would come back here again.
author: Anisha G.

description:
The wine selection is great, and I love the focus on certain wineries every week.  It was through one of these tasting events that I finally got to try Kosta Brown pinots - including the one that soon became Wine Spectator's wine of the year.  I also love the ability to create your own flights of 2 oz pours, and some of the wines on their bar menu are great.

The service, however, is "brisk" to put the most positive spin on things.
author: B. Y.

description:
There was no tasting that afternoon. But I picked up a bottle from the super helpful wine stewards here for Lesly S.'s birthday.

She loved it.
author: Kelly G.

description:
The staff is friendly and very knowledgeable. The tables in the middle of the marketplace provide a great atmosphere for people watching and enjoying the Ferry Building. I'm a wine club member here and I love that I get to have discounted flights of the wines that I didnt receive that month - plus the cheeses that they recommend with each bottle. And yes, they serve all of it with Acme bread - heaven. 

If you come here on a Saturday during the farmer's market, dont expect to get a table any time soon. There are people who show up around 10am to start drinking and get a spot. 

Overall, one of my favorite places to be in the city, especially on a Saturday when you can grab a seat.
author: Holly C.

description:
My last stop of the day Sun 7/22/07.  It was open after 5pm so I was happy.  Most other places at the Ferry Bldg close at 5pm on Sun.  Why so early?  This shop had to close at 6pm today, but it wasn't that time yet.

I don't know much about wine, but I wanted to get 2 bottles that I read about from KQED Bay Area Bites.  These were recommended by one of the bloggers.

They are:

Mt. Tam Vin Gris 2006, $17.  It's so Pink!   Blog mention: http://www.kqed.org/weblog/food/2007/06/think-pink-mount-tamalpais-vin-gris.jsp

Mt. Tam Merlot 2004, $25.  Brought it home, hubby liked it.  Blog mention:
http://www.kqed.org/weblog/food/2007/06/rough-and-red-dy-mount-tamalpais-merlot.jsp

Total for these 2 bottles w/ tax: $45.57!! Yikes.  Credit cards taken.
author: Ann L.

description:
I am loving this place more and more everytime I come.

My first visit was a learning experience because the wines I chose turned out to be fabulous. I came back for more and had an even better experience!

Candice S. and I stopped in after brunch at the Market Cafe and sat down for some Wine at the bar inside this wine shop. This is a great way to try the wines the store offers before you buy. 

We had an awesome Italian wine (2003 Le Sciare Salento Primitivo IGT Cantine Due Palme Apulia (Puglia), Italy) with a block of guyere and some bread and lovely olive spread. 

Unfortunatley they were out of the wine we had, but I got my other fave so I wasn't too bummed. I can't wait to come back again! Perfect date spot. Service at the bar was really good too.
author: Lily M.

description: This is a nice little wine bar in a fun location if you enjoy people watching while sipping.  It's always a little crowded here on the weekends.  Service in my opinion is hit or miss depending on the day.  During the week it's more relaxed.  Cut the wait staff some slack as this is a high volume tourist area.  They have a nice wine selection, knowledgeable staff, and you can bring in some cheesy snacks from the Cow Girl Creamery next door to enjoy with your wine (BIG BONUS!).
author: Kari S.

description:
I've been here several times and previously have liked it a lot. The wine selection is very good and the staff are knowledgable. Food wise the pairings are good but how can you go wrong with Cowgirl Creamery ? 
So what's the problem ? The service. There is nothing worse than standing at a bar and being ignored.
The happy hour ( no special pricing) is packed and food is tourist trap priced. 
I'm over it. I'm sure you've read reviews stating the desire to leave negative stars, uhhh this would be a prime example. 
Scenario one, I come in after work sit at the bar and ask the bartender which food plate he recommends. He barely makes eye contact, shuffles about fitsing w stuff. 
" Uh ..I don't know they are all good" 
" Well which is the most popular ?" 
"Ummmm I'm not sure" 
Lol wow... Thanks so helpful. I then got the ultimate pleasure of listening to the bartenders discuss holiday plans and what they had done the night before. 
After I ordered, I noticed a 25 wine flight on a corner hidden chalkboard. It hadn't even been mentioned to me! 
Thennnn I was pissed. I literally did not leave a tip. I haven't done that in 20? years if ever. 
Scenario 2 I was looking for a magnum or jerabaum sized wine bottle for a gift. 
Begrudgingly I tregged into this place again. I searched for help and found a girl who had been blabbing at the counter the night before. I asked her if they carried this size bottle . With a dirty look she casually waved me in the direction of the " caviar fridge ". One lonely bottle of my size requirement
HORRIBLE TOURIST TRAP
author: Amy P.

description:
The wine selection is really good and the staff in the shop really helpful

BUT 

I was so dissapointed by the staff at the bar.
We had a wine flight and nobody explained the wine.
When we asked a question we just get a short answer.
Thats not what a flight should be like.

Not happy to buy my wine there anymore.
author: feli p.

description: After a terrible service experience at Hog Island Oyster Company, I went with a lifestyle writer to try out the Ferry Plaza Wine Merchants for some wine, cheese, olive, bread and salumi. They used ingredients from amazing local merchants and the pourers were very, very knowledgeable and sweet. Highly recommend it!
author: Pachamama J. B.

description:
every trip to san francisco i find myself at the embarcadero farmer's market on saturday morning.  

thus, every trip to san francisco i find myself sitting at the ferry plaza wine merchant on saturday afternoon, surrounded by way too many packages, oysters and cheese on my table and 3-glasses of that month's red wine flights in front of me.   

over the last couple of years i've become more-and-more familiar with the wonderful selections this shop offers and how knowledgeable the staff are.  they've never let me down or failed to send me home with a less-than-perfect wine choice.  

it doesn't matter what day of the week or time of the day you go - you can depend on the fact you'll be offered excellent wines by people who really know what they're doing.  

this is one of my favorite places in the city to simply sit down and reflect on my day.
author: Mike Q.

description:
Every time we are at the ferry building, I am always tempted to stop in for a glass of wine at FPWM. Yesterday was my birthday, and my BF took me for a mellow night out (we are celebrating this weekend). We had sweetbay oysters and bubbles at hog island and then thought it might be fun to finally check out FPWM. It was relatively quiet and we got an optimal people watching spot. They have a great red & white wine selection but not too many bubble options for sit down service. We ordered the Italian Brut which was really good.

I loved the service we received and ended up signing up for their monthly wine club. Jason (our server) coincidentally had his birthday yesterday too! It was nice to have 'real' conversations with sommeliers/wine servers- the pretentious napa vibe is getting old. If you are looking for a chill place for a wine flight or to pick up a couple of bottles- head here!
author: Seema M.

description: Long time customer of this wine bar and highly recommend stopping in, especially if Silas is in the house. I've had issues with a couple of people here not really interested in you or the reason your here, but Silas for sure will take care of what strikes your taste buds.... great guy and knowledgeable when it comes to the grape. I've gotten some great wines from tasting here. I highly recommend stopping in! If your looking to take a bottle home why not taste it first? By the way, there are some nice meat, cheese and bred options as well..... Cheers to FPWM!
author: Mark J.

description: I love that its at the Ferry Building, I love that they have fresh acme bread and cheese. You can also buy your own lunch etc and they are happy to have you eat it in the wine bar. Im not a big fan of California Wines but I always find something yummy to drink. I tend to stick to bubbles and whites if Im in California Wine country. I prefer to sit at the bar, its busy but I have always felt the bar staff are friendly and helpful. Not so much at the tables.
author: Madrone H.

description: After puttering around the dessert and Spanish wine selections, one of the employees and I had a great conversation on Albarino and other wines of Spain. He made a few recommendations and I ended up with a nice Txakoli and a dessert wine I'd never heard of from Italy. Very friendly, helpful staff that are willing to walk through whatever you want to discuss and try. Also a good selection of obscure bottles that you wont see at most retail stores.
author: Kim N.

description:
We decided to take the ferry to Alameda and go wine tasting at Rosenblum Cellars for my birthday.

We just missed our ferry, and had to wait for the next one. My friend has never been wine tasting, and I was super excited for her to have the experience.

So we sit down at this place in the Ferry Building, to do a flight before boarding the next ferry, which departed an hour later.

No one greeted us for at least 14 minutes. When he did greet us, he didn't say hello, or ask how we were doing. He just finally glanced up and said, I'll be with you ladies "in a few minutes." 

I was so upset at this point, that it's kind of a blur what happened next. All I know is another guy at the counter finally glanced up from doing absolutely nothing, looks at us and stutters, "oh, um..have you ladies not been helped?"

"No we have not." We proceeded to walk out of there, after wasting half an hour sitting there feeling like idiots, wondering why they ignored us, on my birthday.

Also I just want to say there were only about 5 tables occupied when we sat down, and as we waited, more and more people showed up. I know we arrived before them, but we were never GREETED, let alone served. 

I feel so insulted, I have no idea why we were treated this way, and any explanation I can come up with only upsets me more. Thanks a lot guys.
author: Michelle W.

description:
If I could give this place 0 stars I would. I've never been so offended and/or received such poor customer service. 

My business is located nearby and we purchase lots of wine. I found this store very close so I stopped by last week only to be standing at the counter with 2 bottles  waiting patiently for several minutes for someone to ring me up but no one came. I didn't have time to run around the store looking for someone so I had to leave.

Today I thought I'd give it another try, so again I grabbed a couple of bottles and asked the gentleman who had a red vest on where I should purchase the wine (again no one was at the register) and he was so rude and condescending I was shocked. I politely pointed out that last time I was standing at the register for a while and no one assisted me and he just threw his arms up and walked away!

I'm still shocked! Really? Is this how you treat your customers? First you are sarcastic at a genuine question then you turn your head and walk away! I'm still in disbelief! 

Do yourself a favor and go somewhere else, businesses like this (and employees) should not be allowed to treat people like this. You just missed out on a lot of revenue wine merchant.
author: dave f.

description:
This is a great place to taste some new wines b/c they have a wide variety of wines from all over.  Add a cheese plate special that comes with Acme bread and you're set!  

They have wine tasting events all the time and it's a good alternative to those who don't want to drive all the way up to Napa for a tasting experience.
author: Nina L.

description:
I used to buy wine here every week.  Try the tastings at the bar -- I think it's much more fun than going to the restaurants in the Ferry Building for this.  It's pretty economical, too, at least for SF.  The staff was usually very nice here, which I always appreciated when I was a local and came often.  Every now and then you would get someone a bit snobby. 

For our everyday wine, we routinely used the $10 and under wine bin.  Everything is hand selected, so we always had a good experience with it.  

I take that back -- one time, I got a wine that was corked, and they very kindly took it back and gave me another.  Good service.
author: Amber S.

description: Great range and selection of wines. I can spend more time here than any other shop in the ferry building because I can start with tasting at the bar and then wander into the retail space to peruse. If you get a chance to chat with one of their staff members when it's not so busy they provide some really good insight (it's ok you can just nod your head and vaguely understand what they mean about the body, intensity, farming and "essences of" bla bla bla like I do). I feel like they could make some very minor changes to make it more intimate, I think it's a lighting thing.
author: Chris W.

description: My boyfriend and I stop in for a glass/bottle if wine about once a month. We always meet friendly people and discover new and delicious wines. We started getting a cheese plate to take our wine experience to the next level. We really love this place and will continue to have this be a date spot.
author: Nicole P.

description: Decent selection of wines under $40. If you want something more expensive they Have two cooler full of wine. Well, they are full but there is only about 6 different types in each one ranging from $135-$400 a bottle. I'm not from around here so I guess I don't know where to go to get a big selection of collectible wines.
author: Chris O.

description: They don't really have a happy hour here.  Service is a bit slow because there was only 1 person handling the orders and the payment and the seating.  I got the Rose which was very good and the liver patee which was delicious.  Atmosphere is OK, the crowd is a bit older and seems to be more touristy.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
I stopped in here because I was in desperate need of a glass of wine after a long day.  On a Saturday afternoon, it was packed, but I scored a seat at the bar just as someone was leaving.  

The wine selection was good, seemed fairly priced with a good variety to choose from.

I ordered some lemon hummus with bread and was a little sad that it came in its little plastic container.  I understand now that it was from one of the nearby shops, but I never really like buying prepackaged foods from places like this.  It feels a bit like being at the airport or something.  

Anyway, everything was good but the service was a hot mess.  I was served immediately upon sitting down, but then I must've become transparent to my server.  My glass was empty for quite some time and as I looked around, every single customer at the bar was empty or very near empty as well.  There seemed to be no organization amongst the 6 or 7 servers working - they were quite literally everywhere, doing everything.  When they were behind the bar, they were openly complaining about customers, chatting up customers at the bar who were obviously employees after their shifts and each other.  

This place really can't afford to be this disorganized during peak times.  It's a nice place to stop, but be prepared for crappy service.
author: Christy N.

description:
From the existing reviews, it appears that this place is appropriately appreciated.  Nonetheless, my two cents:

I dropped in for a quick bite after a long and trying day.  It was the right move.  I sat in the bar and, after receiving some frank advice about the menu items, picked a nibble that turned out to be just right.  I asked about some wines to purchase to take home, and another guy came by to give me some advice.  I brought one to the table and it was rung up with my dinner.  No muss, no fuss, very relaxing.  

It's all about the service, and the people here know what they're about.

Tourist traffic can be significant, but the ambience here seems to tame egregious behavior.
author: T D.

description: it's an okay spot if you are in the ferry building. We were on a date day so stopped in. It's overpriced with rude service and uncomfy chairs.
author: Deirdre P.

description:
What a great way to people watch on a busy Saturday morning.  Sure we started at 9am, but I was still on Eastern time, so it was noon in my book.  I had the proprietary flight with riesling, chardonnay, pinot noir, and syrah.  I was really impressed by the lack of oak in the chardonnay.  I honestly haven't tried that much California chardonnay in the last few years because I can't stand the oak.  So as the server said, this one is good because it sits on the fence between steel and oak, which happens to be like the French chardonnays that I love - the ones that are aged in old oak so that they don't pick up too much of it.  I also liked the pinot.  Both I would buy, particularly for their price. 

My husband had the specialty flight, and it helped us to find a lovely red from Portugal.  We split the charcuterie plate - delicious, except for the prosciutto, which had gotten soggy from the olive juice or something.

Mostly, I was impressed by the regulars who seem to know all the wines there and the servers who know exactly what to offer them.   I hope that when I open my wine store one day, I can offer the same quality service.
author: Angela M.

description:
We tried this place for the first time today after a suggestion from an out of town friend.  Of all the vendors in the Ferry Building, we somehow missed this gem!  

We seemed to grab the last free table for two at 6:00 on a weeknight.  We ordered a flight of wine (4 partial glasses) and a cheese platter (Cow Girl Creamery--yum!) with seasoned olives & mushrooms to split.  The cheese plate came with a half baguette of Acme bread (yum).  The cheese platter had two half rounds of cheese -- waaaay more than 2 people should ever eat on their own!  It was like BUTTA.  Because the platter had two cheeses, we ended up ordering a second baguette half....and another flight of wine.  The wine flights were good -- a good selection from various regions (Argentina, Spain, Italy, France, etc.) of different types of wine (grenache, rosso, super tuscan, pinot, etc.).  

Wonderful for a mini wine and cheese party!!!
author: Jacqueline C.

description: This was the first place I ever went wine tasting and it was a great experience. Even though the place was packed with people, the bar tender acted like he had all the time in the world for me. He explained all about the wines in our tasting flight and even gave us an extra glass because we were so interested and new at it. I definitely plan on going back very soon!
author: Jeanne J.

description: Great place.  Wonderful service with a knowledgeable staff and great selection.  The fact that they provide food from surrounding vendors only adds to their positive rating.  I highly recommend!
author: Sven D.

description:
hey idiots at the counter last saturday.

when a customer needs a suggestion on wine and wants to buy, please try your best to not look so irritated that i interrupted your conversation about your work schedule or what's a happenin' latuh on tonight.

very similar to pulling teeth, the blonde homely looking chick irritatingly walks away from her convo with her guy coworker (who did not bother helping me either) to pick the first two things she sees. no thank yous, no enthusiam, no upselling, just laying on the thick layers of bitchiness.

im kind of mad at myself for still buying the two bottles after such shitty service. as i am paying my bf comes up to me and as we are both walking out....my bf goes "wow laying on the bitchy service today huh?" i was like "oh my god, you saw that???"

we usually come here every other weekend to buy a bottle of pricey scotch.
not coming back!
author: Tiger Lily ..

description:
Every time I get to visit this wine bar I always leave with a smile on my face. They have excellent selections of wine and love that you can purchase tastes and glasses of wine so you can taste more. In addition the cheese and the pate is really good here. 
Service is really good as well. I was so excited when we were able to secure a table for four on a busy Friday night after work!
 I HEART you Wine Merchant!
author: Maurice A.

description:
There are 2 parts to this establishment and both are really good: the store and the bar.  The store carries a wide range of wine including some excellent, hard to find names (for example, Failla, Merry Edwards and Roar) and even those (and many more) are available to taste at the bar.  While secondary to the wine, the finger food at the bar is from other stores in the Ferry Building and very good.

The Wine Merchant also hosts wine-makers and, again, gets some impressive name (for example, Jamie Kutch).

Only thing to keep in mind as you run over, is that all of the above and the great location in the Ferry Building comes at a price, so be prepared to shell out a few extra bucks...
author: David A.

description:
After eating at Hog's island, my bf, friends and I were looking for a place to just chill for a bit and have a few drinks. We happen to stumble upon this place walking through the ferry building and thought why not give it a try. The place has an area where they have wine to sell and a small area with a few tables and a bar. 

The tables were self seating and on a first come first serve basis. There was no empty tables when we came so we just browsed the area where they were selling wine while we waited for a table to become available. About 15 minutes later a table got up to leave and we were able to sit down. 

We ordered a bottle of cabernet and a plate of cheese and bread to share. It was pretty good. It was a chill vibe and atmosphere with pretty good service. I can see it being a fun place to just come and have a few glasses of wine and people watch. Overall it was a neat experience. Something I could see myself doing again.
author: anna n.

description:
I love wine.  I love the Ferry Building.  Ergo, I love wine at the Ferry Plaza Wine Merchant, right?  Yes, that's right.

Seriously, I've been here several times and it's a nice place to spend time trying new wines and people-watching.  They have a varied selection of wines to try and a detailed guide to help you figure out what you might like.  Tonight I started with a glass of Prosecco and then moved onto the Private Label Flight, which had four 2 oz. pours for only $10.  All were excellent!

We decided to have some snacks (since it was dinner hour and we were famished), so we had one of the cheese and bread appetizers.  Gosh, who can go wrong with Acme bread, Brie, Manchego, and a side of marinated mushrooms and olives?  

I've also gone here alone and the staff is always friendly and helpful, so I'd suggest stopping by the next time you're in the area.  It can get busy, but try to get a table on the outside if possible so you can get your people-watching on!
author: Kimberly B.

description:
Love this place, the wine, the bar, the concept. Only problem is the other customers. I have never been stepped on, shoved, or jostled more than in this place. Wassup - are you all already drunk?

In any case, if you can happen to hit this place when it is not absolutely packed with pushy people, it is a real pleasure. The staff really know their wine, how to serve it, what to serve it with.
author: Susan M.

description: I tried to attend their champagne tasting tonight.  I sat at the bar, ordered the flight, and waited, and waited, and waited and waited.  The bartender never came back.  It was so strange.  I finally left and walked over to Slanted Door.  For the same price as the flight, I had two cocktails & dinner.  Not a bad switch.  Ferry Plaza Wine Merchant must have been having an off night.
author: Chris H.

description:
Venturing through the ferry terminal, I had a bit of time to kill and, like a magnet, was drawn to the Wine Merchant. While I love a good glass of red, I'm always unsure of which bottle to choose. I guess there have been one too many "not good enough" bottles picked off the shelf that makes me question my picking abilities. 

One of the guys who work there (BT, according to my receipt) listened to my description (albeit, lame one) and suggested a handful of bottles within my price range. This couldn't have been an easy task since I'm sure I contradicted myself. After all, if I can like Mexican, Italian & Sushi, I'm sure there is more than one red out there that can tickle my fancy. 

And, now, as I sit here and type, I am fully enjoying a wonderful glass of Five Vintners Zinfandel that is a "full bodied Zinfandel with lots of bright cherry flavors and aromas, a hint of smoky oak and a full complement of that spiciness Zinfandel is known for".  Okay - I swiped that last description - but still true. Because, at the end of the day, it's a learning curve.

For great listening and deciphering skills...  Cheers, BT! 

http://www.yelp.com/biz/five-vintners-saint-helena
author: Jennifer W.

description:
These people are just about the most unresponsive group I've ever dealt with.  I wanted to buy a case (12 bottles) of wine but their website said they only had 11.  I called to see if they can locate 1 more.  They said the computer system shows 14 but will verify and call me back.  5 hours I later I called and they said they can only find 1 on the rack so they'll look for the rest and get back to me.  3 hours later I call and was told that person in a meeting and she will call me as soon as she is done.  1 hour later (closing time) no call back.  I called the following morning and was told that someone else will look for my wine and get back to me later that day.  Again no call back. 

How hard it is to call a customer with a simple status?  Apparently it's not part of Ferry Plaza Wine Merchant's operating procedure.  I ended up spending $1150 on that case of wine with at another store.
author: Kiet V.

description:
Took the family here yesterday for a small snack and a glass of wine before a Peter Pan performance. We ordered different wines which all came out with the right temperature. In addition we ordered a mixed cheese plate which had 2 types of cowgirl creamery cheeses, marinated olives and mushrooms and acme bread. 

We all enjoyed our time here even though the service was a bit slow. Don't get me wrong, our waiter was really friendly and accommodating but it all took a little while. 

The chairs are not the most comfortable ones so stay for a glass of wine and a snack before you continue strolling around in the marketplace. 
And for all the non wine drinkers, they also have a short selection of imported beers.
author: Sonja S.

description: I used to come here to enjoy some wine after work when I worked on Battery Street catching up with old friends, to relax and people watch by default.  Always a great time here and a lively vibe.
author: Shiho F.

description:
FPWM has become my favorite wine bar in the area. The service can be a bit slow and as it is often crowded, but they have a great selection of bottles and with a $6 corkage it's worth it to get one and share it. 

Once I shared a nice Croze Hermitage from Alain Graillot along with a cheese plate with a friend and we really enjoyed it. The cheeses were from Cow Girl Creamery are excellent as is the bread from Acme Bakery. It was a bargain compared to the by the glass prices at some places. 

The best thing about this place though is their Wednesday night wine flight events where the producers attend and talk with you about the wines. I've been a few times and had some excellent flights. I brought my mom and a friend recently and they loved it. It was packed and our server was a bit harried, but after a bit he checked to see how we were doing and we got our orders. 

Then there are the premium events that they hold upstairs were renown wine people come to talk and bring wines to sample. I heard Terry Theise talk about German and Austrian wines and read excerpts from his book. It was a great experience, especially since I lived in Germany and could relate to his stories.
author: Michael L.

description: I've tried sitting at the bar twice in the past six months and unfortunately had the same server (missed getting his name). He had quite an attitude both times, which is unfortunate since bartenders should look at their role to help guide and educate people on the wine offerings. He even had the gall to say to me, "We're busy and there are others waiting if you can't make up your mind." The wine offerings are good, as is the people watching, but will only frequent the store vs. bar. There are plenty of good wine venues in SF and I will not tolerate repeated poor customer service.
author: SF J.

description: My husband and I come to San Francisco at least once a year. We love the Ferry Building and was so happy to come across this wine bar a few years ago. The service here has always been "ok" except for one good occasion where the server was very attentive. But we love the location and that they serve "Cowgirl Creamery" cheese. This last trip to San Francisco for a conference; we try to arrange it in our busy schedule to come here. We made sure we looked at the website to look up the business hours and we even called to confirm. Their website states that on Sunday their store and wine bar hrs are from 10am-7pm.  So on Sunday we arrived at 6pm thinking we have an hour before closing to relax and sip on wine. As we walked up, the bartender didn't wait to say hi or greet us, he just simply did the hand motion "throat slash" that basically states "we are closed" We found this to be very rude. We continue to walk up to the bar and the bartender said the bar closes at 6pm and the store opens till 7pm. Well this is not what is stated on the website, not to mention the bar had plenty of customers. If the bar closes earlier then they need to include this on the website. All in all, we were very disappointed on how this situation was handled. We walked over 2 miles from the hotel and planned on arriving at 6pm!  My husband and I are both in the service industry, and understand that this is unacceptable. Good customer service=repeat customer=word of mouth=free advertisement. Do you agree? We will never return to this place again! What a shame!
author: Cecillia N.

description: Every time i've been in the mood for something and gone in here on my way somewhere, they've had it... and it's always good...
author: Aarash Z.

description:
Great place to have a few glasses before dinner or just to relax with some friends.  You can do a tasting or just do individual glasses of wine.  The best of of Wine Merchant is getting Acme bread with your cheese, it's so good!  The place can get crowded during after work hours but it never gets too bad where you'll want to leave.

You can also buy bottles/cases in the storefront area.  They also have a wine club which seems to be very popular. 

Highly recommend this place, as it's right in the ferry building.
author: Ka C.

description:
What a fantastic establishment. 
Drinking wine while stuffing my face with Mt. Tam Triple Cream and a sourdough baguette is my idea of a fabulous time. Wine, cheese and bread is life. 
What else can I say, they had me at hello.
author: Shani D.

description:
everytime i visit the ferry building, i come here to have a glass of wine. my friend and i decided to order 2 flights today, the April Wine Club Flight (although it is May), and the Private Label Flight. I would recommend the Private Label one over the Wine Club Flight. First of all, it is cheaper by $2. Secondly, it has 1 white and 3 reds versus 2 whites and 2 reds for the wine club flight (i'm a red fan). we also ordered the cheese flight, which was decent, but i'm also not a huge cheese person. the private label pinot is particularly good, as is the cab franc from the russian valley (forget the winery).

overall, great place to sit and relax and have a glass of wine in the middle of the afternoon. it's great being unemployed!

oh, there IS one employee who carries a perpetual frown on her face. $5 to anyone who can get to her laugh just once...
author: Jen C.

description:
Quite frankly, I know nothing about vino...  Before my handsome son started to take me to wineries and wine bars, my wine of choice was Sutter Home White Zinfandel.  I've evolved to a certain degree...

Anyway, I usually go for a beer @ this place.  You can get an Anderson Valley Brewing Company Boont Amber Ale for $3 @ FPWM...

I gotten to the point where I'm considering doing a tasting on Wednesday of Grace Family Vineyards.  The tasting is $49 and due to the scarcity of the wine, their pouring 1oz. pours.  I believe the usual pours are 2oz?  The retail price of the Grace wine is $140 and $335 a bottle...

One of the partners of the joint is Debbie Zacharias who was a co-owner of Bacar.  She's worth the price of admission...

I'm no wine snob, but I love going to Ferry Plaza Wine Merchant!
author: Randal P.

description: OMG! Love this place! We stopped here before catching the Alameda Ferry back. Great wine. We joined the club....
author: Nobbi L.

description:
The Wine Merchant is my second favorite place for wine tasting. I had no real intent on doing a tasting the other night. I went in to the Ferry Building to try Blue Bottle Coffee, and I leave tasting 5 different wines, and a bottle of a 2001 Brunello di Montalcino, rumored to be one of the best vintages in a long time. We shall see. 

I sampled 5 different kinds of wine that night. Every two weeks or so, the Wine Merchant has a tasting of one particular winery. You are given a place mat where all the wines are placed. I learned it's best to sample one wine at a time, staring from the lightest, finish that glass, and proceed to the next wine. Let's just say, I got schooled. 

Along with wine, you may have several kinds of cheese from Cowgirl Creamery, oddly, which you know is also in the building. That along with Acme Bread, you can have a great meal. Salumi plates from Boccalone are available as well. I was alone, and didn't want all that meat and cheese, so I stuck with a baguette and a bowl of nuts.  The nuts were nothing special, perhaps just a bowl of Costco brand.

There are lots of bottles to choose from, and you might find a good one.  Price is quite a bit higher than Hidden Vine.  The tasting of the night cost $40, but some of the glasses have prices of $180 for the bottle, so I assume depending on the winery, the price would be less.  It gets a bit noisy, but I think that was because of the bi-weekly tasting.
author: Michael M.

description: Walked by here maybe a hundred times but never noticed that they offered beer as well as wine. Great selection of both beer and wine and the beer selection also had great prices. Had wine, beer and then an empanada nearby.. Great way to unwind
author: Bill P.

description:
I have come to this place for awhile now and I can only say I want to own it.
Oh come on it would be great .
Let's do it.
We could set up work right from here .
Believe me I know a few guys across the country that actually hold court at restaurants all afternoon with their employees. 
Of course they have more money than God so they can.
So, let's start small, only Fridays.
Come on , what are you afraid of.

And.....

They have a  knowledgeable staff that rocks, always up for bringing a taste of a wine and turning you on to the newest and  the hippist .
author: Katherine N.

description: I wish I had more time to come here more often. Great spot to unwind and have a flight of wines and a cheese plate. Its nice to have unexpcted gems like this around town.
author: Huy T.

description:
I like presents. If you're not bearing gifts, don't bother me. Fortunately, my bad behavior is frequently rewarded with gifts from the main man in my life. Lucky me! 

Sometimes, if I stay out til 6 a.m. on a weekday with my crazy friends, and I come home raving and raging like a lunatic, and I'm really really bad, Boy even buys me delicious wine at this location. I love this place! 

When I see that bag come through the door, I know I did something right (and oh so wrong) the night before. Great selection of Malbecs and proseccos and cavas at all price points, including $10-$20 range! I'm a cheap date (well...just cheap) and even I am very satisfied. Great service too and the staff is very knowledgeable and helpful. No attitude and great prices? Unbelievable for the Ferry Building, but all true.
author: Autumn K.

description:
This was my second time here and this time was much more crowded since it was a Saturday.  We waited patiently for a space to open up since the place was mobbed.  My friend even asked two women if we could share their table and they were so rude.   They shifted from the outside chairs they were sitting on to make sure no one else would ask them to share.  We just let it go.  Whatever!

One person left the bar and the rest of the people at the bar were kind and moved down so we could both sit down.  We focused on the nice people around us who let us enjoy our visit.   

We ordered a glass of rose, which was nice but not spectacular.   And ordered the Gruyère and burratta cheese.  Both were amazing with the fresh Acme bread and the heirloom tomato and olive tapande.  For our second glass, we asked for a recommendation and had a fabulous Albarino.   My friend went in search of some wine in the store and they just added it to our tab.  The selection was really nice and the people working there were working very hard but were super nice.
author: Ayelet B.

description:
UPDATE:  
I've recently received some emails from Ferry Plaza Wine Merchant for special tasting flights/events at a much lower price point than the one I complain about in my original review.  I've been to one so far and while the premise was interesting and the wines were good, I felt as if the service level wasn't what I expect at a tasting event.  In their defense, it was insanely busy but we really received no information about the wines beyond the little notes with the flight.  I would come back for a drink with friends or to buy a nice bottle but that is really it.

ORIGINAL REVIEW:
This place gets five stars for their eclectic and unique selection (small production, hard to find wines - yay!) but I dropped stars for two reasons:

First, I've had two bad experiences coming to pick a wine - one staff member actually rolled his eyes when I asked for a sparkling wine that was not Brut (I don't like the super dry champagnes).  Most of the time I get excellent service and I do keep coming back, but if the snotty attitude comes out again I'm moving permanently to K&L.

Second reason - high priced specialty tasting flights.  On many an occasion I have wanted to come try the special flights with the guest winemakers, but $75??  I just can't do it, and I think it's overpriced.  I know, they are limited production wines but still...

So, overall - a great place to find that wine nobody else at dinner will have, but I do not vouch for consistency of service.
author: Suzanne B.

description:
I really love this place!
 It's a great place to stop buy to pick up a few bottles, or to have a few glasses of wine. Not pretentious at all!  This is a great place to go after work or when in casual clothes and just relax.

 What is it about wine that relaxes me so much? I have no idea, but I know this place makes the experience so much better. 

so go get drunk!
author: Marlene D.

description:
I'm conflicted.  By all appearances, it's a cute shop, in the perfect location to grab a bottle of wine on your way to the ferry.  Seems like a decent selection and a good way to learn more about wine, albeit on the pricey side.

However, I was really taken aback with the attitude I got when I confessed I didn't know a lot about wine but wanted to get a gift for a friend and described what I understood of her taste.  I got this whole Starbucks mentality where they refused to understand me because I wasn't speaking their jargon-specific language.  

(Tangent:  If I can go into any coffee shop on the planet and order a small double non-fat latte without incident, why can't Starbucks translate that into whatever made-up name they serve and just give it to me without the language lesson EVERY. SINGLE. TIME.??)

Back to my wine purchase... I got really frustrated and felt like a naughty learning-disabled kindergartner and almost walked out without getting any wine.  But I'm a sucker and was in a time crunch, so I got the bottle and got the heck outta there.  For the record, they got it right -- my pal loved the wine.  But I'm not willing to go back there again.  They might smack my hands with a ruler or something.
author: Andi T.

description:
A charming spot to stop for a glass of wine and a snack, and even better spot for some serious people watching.

Their tasting menu changes weekly, so you kind of never know what you're going to get, but your bar tender will be happy to steer you in the direction of something good, especially if you're lucky enough to get Salvatore, he's terrific.

Along with our wine we enjoyed some heirloom tomato and olive tapenade with gruyere cheese, and some pate, both were delicious.  I had the flight of the month which included two reds and two whites, the sauvignon blanc was my favorite of the four.  But the real star of our tasting was the French champagne my friend ordered, we ended up enjoying several glasses of that, it complimented the food we ordered just beautifully.  Unfortunately I'm lame and forgot to write down the name.  Oh well, I guess that just means I've got to go back again soon.
author: Renae H.

description: Great place to enjoy a bottle of wine. They offer a simple menu of cheeses and charcuterie which is perfect. Most of the staff is super nice and helpful except an older guy that works on the back tables. It seems that he's not very happy to be working there. Not my fault!
author: Rebecca P.

description: We come up to San Francisco from San Diego about every other month. This place is a must visit for us on every trip. The service is great the people watching is outstanding. Jason one of the bartenders is awesome. Always has time for you even when it is really busy. And being able to shop at the surrounding eat
author: Michael L.

description: I have been coming here for the past several years whenever I layover in SFO.  I absolutely love the selection of wines that FPWM has to offer and I  love that you can hang out at the market, taste some great and unique wines, enjoy a cheese plate and meet lots of new and interesting people.  Silas is my favorite sommelier and always offers wonderful selections to try. Check it out the next time you re in San Francisco. This is some fun wine tasting with no pretense or snobbery!
author: Laurel W.

description: This is a great place to stop by when you're in-between shopping and dinner.  It's a seat-yourself and sit as long as you want type of place.  I would give it five stars if I liked the wine selection more.  We did order olives and mushrooms and some cheeses with Acme bread, and we loved it.
author: Tracy L.

description: The worst wine I've ever had. We tried the wine flight and of the 4 wines none were drinkable. Another member of our party ordered a recommended glass and it was terrible too. Service was friendly but NOT worth it.
author: Michelle M.

description:
I come here often.  I feel at home in the Ferry Building. The food and the foodies, the gleeful tourists, the commuters awaiting their ferry ride home, the winos. The Wine Merchant offers a wonderful in-house wine list. Tastes, half pours, glasses. Tasty wine fare to boot.  

It's the service or lack thereof that  I struggle with here. My friends and I typically wait quite awhile to be acknowledged.  And then the wine can take even longer. I question why they can't hire more staff - they're doing a good business. it's like they forget that a lot of us are locals ( and wine club members) and aren't tourists that they'll never see again ( they should treat tourists as locals too!). For the most part, the servers aren't personable - they seem to want you in and out. I've had the same experience in the shop. it's odd to me because most of the wine bars or shops I hit boast wonderful, warm attentive staff. 

I keep going back because I like to be in the Ferry Buidling. Also, the Wine Merchant offers  a good pour and good wine - and buzz, not just from the wine, but the building and its surroundings permeate into the wine shop.   You feel like you're on vacation, which is something I enjoy. 

Alas, i'll keep going back....
author: Carson R.

description:
my fave part of this place is the bar, its fab wines-by-the-glass selection, and people-watching while perched upon bar stools. with the nibbles, don't forget the nibbles.

the store wine selection is also quite good, albeit pricey. you pay for what you ask. 

if you are tempted to attend any number of their heavily publicized tastings, I would advise a) getting there really early to grab standing room, and b) girding up with a lot of patience for drunken crowds.
author: Sasha R.

description:
This place seemed great from the outside and their wine selection was impecable but the service was one of the worst experiences ever!!!  We sat at a table and no one approached us so we sat at the bar.  We were ignored at the bar too and asked for help and the waiter was so rude and unhelpful we almost left at that moment.  Then we had to solicit help from a girl there who did not look like she even had a job there as she was in a dirty sweatshirt and looked high or too tired to work, and she was so ditsy and charged my associate twice for the bill even though we gave her cash and a card and asked her to take the cash off.  If I ever go here again it will just be for purchases as the staff was uninviting and rude.  They were also making cheese and snack plates and no one washed their hands as they went from register and money and cheese and meat.  I would not be surprised if someone got sick from their lack of care.

Skip this place you are better getting a bottle and going to your hotel!
author: Miss S.

description:
I spy a few recent Yelp bashings here.  Fortunately for me, this wasn't the case.

Spent a couple of hours here (yeah, not the first time) drinking champagne and watching scary tourists stroll by.  We sat at the bar and the staff was just the right amount of friendly.  I'm planning on going back for a champagne flight tasting later in the week.  

Do you know a better way to spend a cloudy, drizzly Sunday afternoon?
author: Lil P.

description:
Sunday morning:

I roll out of bed and hop in the shower.  I get ready to go meet my parents...where am I going you ask?  The ferry building!  Now, I do love the ferry building, so yes I was more than excited.  I got there and dad suggests we go try some wine out...good idea!  Or maybe not?  No brekkie=Intoxication!  The wine was pretty great...went well with the herb slab from Acme and all was well.  I suppose I'll go back...but because of the location.  The people working there really didn't take time to talk to us and it wasn't busy at all.
author: Jess S.

description:
If I knew that this was the place I was meeting folks at on Friday night, I might have balked at attending.  I'm not a wine guy at all.  Having said that, they do serve beer, so my heathen tastes were satisfied.  I even ordered a glass of wine and enjoyed it.
This place was very busy, but we were treated well.  The 3-4 guys behind the counter were hustling and taking care of people.  The wine  list is detailed and extensive.  There are also many price points on it, so if something catches your eye, make sure to check the price at the bottom of the description, because there are $6 glasses of wine, and $19 glasses of wine.  
On the surface, I wouldn't call this my kind of place, but after spending a couple of hours here and being treated well I will definitely be back.  This place won me over with the kind of service that everyone should try to emulate.
author: Nelson W.

description:
I first went to the wine merchant for wine tastings - they have a monthly tasting with different wineries (or they used to) which is really fun and allows you to try a lot of wines.  there is a small area of tables in the front with seating.  great way to enjoy the ferry building while sitting and having a glass of wine!  
but they also have a great selection of wines from around the world.  most recently i was there looking for a south african wine to bring to a friend's house.  the service was great - the salesperson that i talked with was very helpful and recommended several wines.  my friend was also looking for a french wine, and his selection was our favorite of the night!
author: Carolyn B.

description: Helpful staff, nice little menu of snacks, and an easy, comfortable atmosphere.
author: R. O.

description:
I've taken 2 wine tasting classes here facillitated by Peter Granoff and have really enjoyed his presentation and the information given during the classes. 

The only improvement I would make is for them to serve or offer food before or after the classes that are scheduled at 6:30pm. These classes are right at dinner time and some of us might need to eat something before we drink 5 glasses (albeit half full glasses) of wine. 

So, if you're going to a wine tasting class here...be sure to get something to eat first!!
author: Cindy K.

description:
I took the beginning wine class and was definitely worth the $50!

The sommelier knew a ton about wines, we tasted 3 whites, 3 reds & 1 bubbly rose. They provided bread, bottled water and a bucket to spit in.

The class took place in a conference room on the second floor of the ferry building and had a stunning view of the bay bridge. Very good atmosphere!

I can't wait to go drink more wine...take me to napa!
author: Elaine S.

description: Really good petit sirah. Barstools were not very comfortable but it is a good place to take out of town guests.
author: Michelle R.

description:
Single women-Your mission if you choose to accept it:  Go to a different bar every week by yourself without any of your usual accessories.  Meaning, no books, magazines or fun gal plans.  Of course I didn't mean you couldn't wear fabulous shoes and jewelry.

I got this idea from my gay boyfriend.  Once upon a time he went to a bar by himself every week and had a Martini.  I accepted the Mission and decided to switch it to wine bars.  I love wine, we live in Northern California, it was an obvious choice!  But why am I doing it, you may ask.  Well, I'm a grown woman, independent, smart, funny and I should damn well be able to go out and enjoy my own company.

For my first wine bar, I choose the Ferry Plaza.  I figured low key, laid back and people are actually interested in drinking wine.  I went in after work on a Tuesday (as part of the Mission you must go on an off night) and sat at the bar.  So far, so good, no one shouted, "OH MY GOD, THERE IS A SINGLE GIRL HERE," and ran away in fear.

I choose a glass of wine from there menu.  I enjoy the menu because it tells a story about each wine.  I choose the "Aries" because it was a story from World War II.  I like history and I LOVED the wine.  I'm not a big drinker of white, but I would definitely recommend it to those who come after me.  

I sat by myself, thought over the days events and the events to come and truly enjoyed myself.  No one stared or looked at me like I was crazy.  Just a woman enjoying a glass of wine.  

AND, I got a desert wine to go with the Pumpkin Pie I'm going to make when I invite friends over.  All in all, a good trip.  

Tune in next week as I'll be doing this every week for the remainder of year.
author: Jachyn D.

description: Great wine shop.  Only reason I'm not giving 4 stars is because I wasn't able to have a tasting there.  They have a great selection of California and French wines for their size.  Bought a nice Rose and Syrah.  Can't wait to open them.
author: Carolyn W.

description:
One of the most visible wine bars of the city. It's situated right in the Ferry Building, so just about every business person and their dog know about this place. However, this doesn't make it the best.

Still, they certainly have a large, healthy selection, which seems thoroughly selected for the discerning public's consumption. I just wish their food pairings were given as much consideration. Several times I've seen cheese on their menu, the likes of which I could get for a third of the price at 2X the size at Safeway. Strange that they don't collaborate with Cowgirl Creamery just a few doors down. 

The people working here are very informative and efficient. They are happy to offer suggestions and descriptions, and are always up for short witty table conversation here and there. They're okay with people bringing in outside food (within reason) for their own pairings. When the small seating area is full, you can still enjoy a stroll through the store as you survey their bottles. Check out the Louis XIII cognac behind the glass - wow.
author: Clar L.

description:
K says: We went here on a Thursday evening, a beautiful summer day, and had a great time. All seats were full with after-work drinkers, a few tourists, a few on dates, and some "students" doing their wine homework.
