We ordered some cheese, some italian meats, and of course, a few glasses of wine. The cheese and meats were good, and worth ordering. Our server accomodated our blind tasting request, and we had a lot of fun with it! I'd definitely go back again. 

J says: Great unpretentious service and good selection for tastings.  The cheese plate was very substantial for two people and the garlic mushrooms and olives that came with it were awesome.
author: Jen Ken H.

description: My wife and I have been a members of the FPWM Mixed Wine Club selection for a year or so. We joined because we know less than nothing when it comes to wine. While being a wine club member hasn't made me a wine intellectual, we have tried  and been exposed to some really nice and for the relatively affordable wines (@$18-22). The descriptions are great and they come with a recipe for a proposed dish to accompany the wine. It's fun and we're getting hands on experience with wine.  The staff is really nice and knowledgable. And the membership discount has come in handy.
author: Will C.

description: Great wine selection in store. Nice appetizers and wine choices at the bar including 2 or 5 oz pours as well as split or full bottle. Nice place to sit enjoy a glass of wine some chesse and salami and watch the world walk by.
author: Tim S.

description:
Super impressed with the knowledgeable staff at the FPWM.  I also love their rating system.

I was actually DIScouraged from buying a $30-something wine and was persuaded to buy a bottle that was about $10 less and am-a-azing. http://www.ottimino.com

Given their location, they could mark up their wines and people would buy them -- but surprisingly, their vino is well-priced and I've heard their wine club is also superb.

Update  4/07: Joined their wine club as a gift for my dad.  Wines arrived promptly, accompanying info about the wine and recipes to match were awesome, the wine was great and well-priced.  My dad has never been so excited for something to arrive in the mail!   A+
author: Heather C.

description: Nice selection of interesting wines at the wine counter for tastings/flights.
author: Randy R.

description:
Love this place.

Mainly because they have a phenomenal champagne selection.  Perfect post-farmers market stop to grab a bottle in preparation for a big night out.  Sipping a bottle of bubbly while I primp?  There's nothing better (and I do mean the whole bottle!).  

And not just any champagne.  There's no run-of-the-mill Veuve here.  Instead you'll find sublimely crafted, fantastically obscure bottlings from teeny tiny producers.  These guys are the real deal: at the bottom of the label, you'll see a tiny "RM": this means "recoltant manipulant", and indicates they grow the grapes for their champagne.  Sounds like not-a-big-deal, but over 90% of champagne houses don't do this.  I love exclusivity!

I also love finding similarly obscure white burgundies that taste as if they cost three times their very reasonable price.  But I don't love not being able to find that same bottle two weeks later.  Wait, did I say I love exclusivity?  Not that much.  And I also don't love being steered toward a watery and insipid red burg that only reminds me how disappointing pinot noir can be.  I guess not even great staff can hit the mark with every reco.

But that champagne makes up for everything.
author: Melissa B.

description: Very nice little place, we have tried the O'Connor pinot noir and the house pinot noir, both tasty. Positive note of this wine shop is that you can bring your own "aperitivi" from any of the nearby shops and have while sipping on some good vino. Prices aren't too bad either, very balanced.
author: Giorgio B.

description:
I've been to the wine bar here a few times with friends. After work, it's usually crowded and can be hard to find a table. The menu comes in a binder, so you think that there will be dozens of wines to try. In reality, they have fewer offerings that most of the other wine bars in the City. Let's say you want a moderately-priced red. There might be only one choice that day. Like most businesses in the Ferry Building, prices are high but reflect the quality.

I go elsewhere to purchase wine, though they have a large, well-considered selection. Once I went there to buy a gift box for a bottle I had purchased elsewhere. Big mistake. For the price of a box, I could have gotten myself an inexpensive bottle somewhere else.
author: Timothy O.

description: The wine list is definitely made for people that know wine. We had a hard time choosing between selections of Cornas, Piemonte, Loire Valley, Friuli  etc . Not a Napa in the bunch (altho the Alex Valley Silver Choke seemed to be thrown on there to satisfy the sad-sacks that don't know how to branch out and try something new). Killer cheese selection with Acme bread and it's all reasonably priced. Like others, I found the service sorely lacking. What ... they couldn't hire another server on a packed Friday night? The poor guy had to cover about 20 tables and he spent more time averting out gaze even tho our water and wine glasses were empty most of the time. Might be best to order two glasses at a time if you don't want a long wait between them.
author: Robin S.

description: Fun late afternoon wine and cheese service, good selection of both old and new world wines.
author: Julia D.

description:
Smallish  but decent collection of styles and price ranges and I generally find staff knowledgable. They've given over some more of the retail space to the wine bar, so I rate this now as a wine bar not a retail outlet. There are many better retailers in the bay area.
But the wine bar is fun. Again a decent selection, not huge. But the vibe is fun and a seat on the marketplace side can while away time people watching. 
They do some nibbles, but are cool about you bringing some cheese from cowgirl or bread from acme. That's a good mix I think because there are such great foodie places in the building but sometimes you can't be bothered you know? You just want the cheese and olives to arrive.
Good for a few quiet ones or a quick glass on the way to the ferry so you don't have drink the rubbish on the GG ferry (stick to beer on the ferry!).
author: Tony S.

description:
If you work downtown, this is the place to go to pick up a bottle of nice wine on the way to a dinner party, as well as to sit down and enjoy a flight after work. The retail staff has been extremely helpful whether I was looking for something specific or needed tips for "what goes with X." If you're staying for a glass, you can now also buy a box of cheese and snacks (all local and mostly organic) to moderate that blood sugar. 

I could give it a 5th star if the wine (bottles or glasses) didn't cost 10-20% more than average, but like everything else in the beautiful Ferrry Building, I'm just glad it's there!
author: Gretchen T.

description:
What a perfect little place for a post  work get together with a good friend! I love that you can order by the taste to create your own flight, or get a full glass. The cheese and mushrooms with fresh bread is also a perfect light, though decadent, dinner when you dont feel like cooking once you get home.

Im not sure why I dont feel inclined to go all the way to five stars - maybe its the tall stools in the bustling ferry building, rather than a dark, intimate locale, or the fact I would like to pair a cheese tasting with the wine tasting, which is not fair given its a wine shop and not a wine and cheese shop. Maybe I'll go to five after the next visit since I definitely plan to be back soon!
author: Lise L.

description:
Speaking as someone that was enrolled in the wine club program for 3 months, this is a GREAT PLACE. My sweetheart Alice L. bestowed this on me as my Xmas/Bday and i was SO excited! Its a gift that just keeps giving! Every month I got to pick up 2 bottles of wine, and EVERY BOTTLE suited me. I got to taste wine I'd ordinarily be reluctant to try or just thought I wouldn't enjoy. An educational & eye-opening expereince! (I thought I hated Cabernet Sauvignon... WRONG!) They even include recipes and a taste guide to correspond with the 2 bottles each month. I haven't tested any of the recipes yet, but i'm definitely intrigued by them.

The staff was equally impressive. Really helpful & super friendly! I've yet to hang out at the bar, but it will happen soon enough!
author: Ikeb I.

description: The wine selection is large for the amount of space they fill it in. The wine tasting section was closed off because my boyfriend and I were browsing around before our dinner reservations. But when I asked the workers if there was any way I can try their Ferry Market Cabernet Sauvignon 2009, they said they can "pour me a smidge." He poured me enough for me to try with my boyfriend. The cab was medium bodied with a sharp note of blackberries and a smooth finish of mocha. So I ended up buying 2 bottles at $12 each. They have a section of their wines that are in the $12 range which is very respectable. The wine is a 50% mix of Napa grapes and 50% Medecino grapes. The friendliness of the staff to the "Nor Cal" wine atmosphere was shaped for tourists but also super local. We are definitely coming again to see their new selection and of course earlier for the wine tasting!
author: Wendy L.

description:
Let me start off by saying the food and wine here was amazing. From the Acme bread to the Cowgirl Creamery Cheese down to the marinated mushrooms. Great local cheese selection, and equally good wines--that is the only reason they should receive one more star.

That being said, I've never encountered service this horrible in my life. After being questioned about my ID (fine I'll take that, I'm a local but I guess I can look young) it only went down hill from there. It took forever for the server to even greet us, and honestly that was the extent of our interaction. I don't know if he thought we were "too  young" or thought we wouldn't tip well off the bat or something, but I am a discerning foodie who frequents restaurants quite often. He acted bothered when we ordered food, and it got to the point where, when attempting to get his attention to order more wine, he simply glanced over his shoulder never stopping or uttering a word. He did, however, pay attention to every other table than ours--it is worth mentioning that they were hardly busy, and not as crowded as others have described. It ended up another staff member who took our second order, and again another to finally bring our bill after motioning several times to get the attention of our original server. I mean, I'm not picky but not once did he ask how we liked anything. Now this friend of mine was in town visiting, and can you imagine my embarrassment at having been treated so poorly?

Fighting every urge to give this man the worst tip possible, we very graciously gave him a generous tip along with "Thanks for the great service!" written on the bill. I wanted to give the Ferry Plaza Wine Merchant a try, but I will definitely never go back again and if I do, I will avoid the bald man. You will most likely have better luck than me!
author: Ashley H.

description:
I know I keep giving 4 or 5 stars to everything I did so far in San Francisco, but y'all have an awesome city!!

So another place we had heard about was the wine merchant inside the ferry building. Having walked around for the better part of the morning, we were ready to chill out and sit down for a bit. Is 11 am too early to have wine and cheese? Hells no! 

The bartender (? server?) dude was very very nice and enthusiastic. Instantly my smile, already there because I was sitting down and thinking about wine, got a little larger when he was getting excited about the wines and cheese offerings. We ended up with a small round of cheese that was from somewhere in Vermont, and we each got a drink. It was a bit pricey, but no bother - I was on vaca darnit!

Oh. I should mention something else I really loved about this place. Primo people watching spot - we had one of the tables right on the outside, so we were able to check out the goings on around us, the marketplace chaos, tourists (pshaw), and entertaining baby situations. And it's easy to see people crinkling their noses at the mushroom place across the way, which I found pretty funny.

All in all, let your barking dogs rest here and make this a stop on your grand tour of awesome things to do in San Fran!!
author: Purvi R.

description:
Its been awhile, tho well worth the trek cross town or bart across the bay.
I like the convivial staff, modest nosh and great happy hour wine deals. GO and live large on a beer budget.
author: One P.

description: This review is solely based on my experience at the wine bar, which left much to be desired. Yes the wine selection is very good and the ACME bread and cheese offerings are excellent. And I like the setting. But what ruined the whole experience was the A**hole bald dude manning the bar. C'mon guy, if you can't be civil, don't sign up for a job that requires human interaction. This guy was so rude, why would we return? And, how does he keep his job (unless he owns the place)? San Francisco has tons of wine bars and/or restaurants with solid by-the-glass options served by warm, pleasant people. Adios FPWM!! I'm not gonna miss ya.
author: Lisa M.

description:
A really pleasant way to spend a late afternoon or evening...

Great wines...you can taste everything----lots of gradations of pours.  I can kill a few hrs here, easily.  Lots of wines for sale that are great tasting & reasonable.

Minus a star for the masses.
author: Holly F.

description:
We all know what the ferry plaza is.  A haven for really expensive, really fresh, really amazing food.   Oh, and as some people like to point out, there are tourists--loads of them.  Well, you know what?  We live in San Francisco--a world center of tourism.  And the ferry building's food is world class.  
The wine at this wine merchant is delicious.  Especially their selection of California wines.  It is a great place.  There are tourists, there are bridge and tunnel types, there are locals--just deal with it.  It is a great wine store with a great wine bar.  Grab a bit of cheese from the Cowgirl Creamery and some bread from Acme, and have a glass of wine at the bar.  How can you complain?
author: Blake W.

description:
Love this place.  Best part: very very affordable -- especially on bottle.  Granted, it is inside the ferry building, so it has a bit of a mall feel, but it's a great pit stop for good wine at very affordable prices.  Great for a drink before dinner in the financial district or embarcadero.

Their cheese plate menu is minimal, but they have a really nice selection for the variety plate -- a little taste of everything.

Love their sparkling -- surprisingly the cheaper one is better in my opinion cuz I'm not a fan of oaky flavors.
author: Latef X.

description:
pretty good wine list. lots of wine available. big pours. don't get sticker shock. a glass of wine for $9. It's a lot. you can get food if you like. 

there's also private tastings available.
author: Andrew Y.

description: This place has a really good vibe.  Happy customers having a good time over a glass or bottle of wine.  Hubs and I got lucky and scored a table right away amidst the insane crowd.  We each got a glass of wine and chose gruyère with tapanade.   The cheese selection was disappointing but the Acme bread that they served was delicious.  Wine options were good enough.  Service is poor- our server seemed flustered and frazzled the whole time and didn't even say anything to us.  We ordered, he delivered. Eh, it was ok but I wouldn't go back.
author: Lanna K.

description: We came here for some wine while on a trip from LA since we didn't want to spend all of our money buying wine in restaurants. The lady working there was super helpful and hooked us up with a great bottle that was inexpensive but still delicious.
author: Caitlin Z.

description:
Perfect place.  Who would've thunk ?  Grocery/farmer's market shopping, and then wine tasting.

I like going to this place w/ a tasty burger from Taylor's.  Nothing like a juicy burger w/ an awesome glass of chianti or syrah.  Yummy...

The sommelier is awesome.  She's both very knowledgeable and just wonderful.
author: Rod '.

description:
I had the pleasure of helping somebody spend a sizable gift card here. I grabbed some fresh bread from Acme and two semi-firm cheeses from Cowgirl to accompany our wine foray. The Ferry Plaza Wine Merchant has a decent handful of cheeses on their brief menu, but I was in the mood to try something new. I love that FPWM welcomes outside food. Our waiter saw the bag and brought us a cheese board and knife right away, great service. 

We created a few different flights with the intention of buying a bottle to enjoy at the wine bar. Our tastes included the following: 2 oz pours of the Bodegas Matilde Totus Tuus Cava and Pierre Moncuit Grand Cru, 2008 Domaine Moreux Sancerre Chavignol, 2007 Brooks Janus Pinot Noir, 2007 Daedulus Labyrinth Pinot Noir, and the 2006 Tolaini Valdisanti Toscanna Rosso. After tasting the Sancerre, I was certain that's what I wanted! It was perfectly crisp, with subtle citrus (ie not overbearing melony fruit), minerality, and a clean light finish. My tasting partner was in the mood for red though. At this point, I noticed that despite sitting amidst the retail bottles watching people scurry by in the ferry building, FPWM had a good buzz about it. Many seats were full and everybody was having a great time even though it was mid-week. My main complaint is that the stools are not very comfortable, in fact they are down-right uncomfortable. Otherwise, I think we would have been willing to while away the entire evening there. However, we opted to grab a bottle of the Brown Estate Napa Valley Zin (with the scarab on the label) and finish off the night at home. 

Aside from the stools, FPWM gets a thumbs up. I found absolutely no sign of pretension there in any of the staff and highly recommend picking up a bottle of that Sancerre...in case summer ever shows its face around here.
author: Candice L.

description: Cheese? Bread? Olives and wine? Yes, please.
author: Joan S.

description: Not a wine drinker, so I can't comment on selection.  However, this is a great place to have a party (assuming you cater it yourself).  Management is great at helping you select wines, cheeses, and food from local eateries.  It can be a little loud if your group is larger than 20, but overall, a very nice venue.
author: Mike F.

description: Great wine bar. We enjoyed the wine flights and cheese plate. Good service.
author: Frank W.

description:
Just accompanying a friend on the search for a birthday present.  Neither one of us knows much about wines, so we were impressed with the very helpful workers who took the time to tell us about the various wines, and helped my friend find the perfect accompaniment to go with the delicious chocolates in her hands.  

They paid attention to what she was looking for, the price range, and from a brief description of her husband's wine tastes, we both felt she had the perfect bottle in her hands.  

I love the variety offered here.  I love the little knick-knacks sold by the cash registers.  I love the wine bar on the side.  I only wish I enjoyed wine more.
author: Denise M.

description:
Not only is this place great to visit on a leisurely weekday afternoon, but perfect after a nice lunch at Slanted Door, or really - just for the hell of it.  The entire Ferry Building is great to visit - all the markets, cheese, butchers, etc...

Three things I really adore about this place:

1)  You can pick out a stellar wine and enjoy it, right there, on the spot at one of their tables and chit chat with your guests or simply people watch all the folks cruising by.

2)  The wine is really affordable and the selection is fantastic - french to domestic, Spanish to new zealand.

3)  They carry one of my absolute favorite wines, that i find extremely difficult to find anywhere else - Crement d'Alsace, a 100% pinot noir sparkling rose...  If you ever get the chance, you MUST try it.  It's perfect for brunch, a sunny afternoon or just because.

I will never visit the ferry building without hitting up the wine merchant for my vino addictions!
author: Kris I.

description: This place obviously does not like customers. Had a fabulous time at the other places in the Ferry building but when we decided to end our day buying a bottle if wine and relaxing with our cheese and bread purchases, we were left with a bitter taste when the bill came and they charged an exorbitant corkage fee...and while I can understand a fee to open a bottle brought in from somewhere else, this was a bottle from their own stock! It just seems inappropriate... Will never give them my business again.
author: Tana C.

description:
Loud and actually a bit breezy sometimes despite being inside the Ferry Building, this place is my wool sweater.  It's always a great place to catch a drink after work with friends.  

The location makes it great for transit accessibility for those coming from the City or the East Bay, not to mention both the wine and food selection provide a great assortment of the regions' finest.  I'm a total sucker for the Sonoma Coast reds they carry along with some Acme bread with either Humboldt Fog or Point Reyes cheese.  

I've actually had some of my greatest entrepreneurial business ideas while sipping on a smooth glass of Pinot with friends here; that said, unfortunately none of these ideas have actually ended up making enough money to pay for the glass of wine... so I guess I should have another glass, right?  ...and either drown my sorrows or  think of some better ideas!
author: WW R.

description: What a selection!  The Robert Sinskey Pinot Blanc is one of my favorite half bottles of wine, and the Ferry Plaza Wine Merchant carries it!  The shop also carries lots of other great, hard-to-find wines like the Brown Estate Zinfandel that I adore.  The service is great and friendly.  You can also buy a bottle of wine at the shop and drink it right there!
author: Wendy L.

description: Living near the Ferry Building, it's great to have FPWM in the neighborhood.  The selection steers clear of many of the major labels, and he focus here is on California wines, although they have a very well-thought selection of European wines as well.  I knew it was a good sign when I walked in and found my favorite cabernet franc from Lang & reed.  The wine bar is a great place to try samples and flights, but the only down-side is that it may be hard to get a seat.   The menu changes constantly and on a few occasions, they brought out other wines as well.
author: Peter L.

description: Love it!  Sometimes I walk EXTRA slow so I miss the 6:20 ferry to Larkspur. Oh no, I have to wait until 7:20.  I guess I'll just have to sit at the bar at the Wine Merchant, sample a delicious flight of reds, or maybe the Chilean wines.. or maybe whites.  Ok, twist my arm. Bring me some of that cheese. Yum. And that cute little baguette. And all those tasty salamis and cured meats.  The scene is hip, the people watching fantastic, and vibe welcoming. The wine is so good I think I will step into the wine shop and buy a bottle or two!  And if I miss the 7:20 ferry? There is always the 8:10.
author: Nora F.

description:
I discovered this wonderful gem as it's the perfect place to meet friends, prior to jumping onto the ferry to Sausalito to enjoy juicy burgers and the wonderful view.  But I digress.  

Wine Merchant has been a tried and true friend to me and my social activities, as each time I've set up a meeting with random friends, a table has opened up within minutes, and the perfect glass of wine is in my hands a few minutes later.  Food?  Is there food, do you ask?  Well, it's not a meal, but don't skimp on the cheese and meats plate.  The bread is always a delightful shape (and it's Acme bread, best in the bay area!), and it's like a "deconstructed sandwich", a la Top Chef, where delightful combinations can be construed, it's just limited by your imagination (and the three different cheeses and two different dried sliced meats)!  But I love this place.  I shall remain loyal, and that isn't the wine speaking!
author: Ria D.

description:
This place made me feel right at home.  I went in solely to have a couple of tastes and was super happy with my trio of rose, Spanish something and non oaked chardonnay.   I finished with a glass of riesling for "dessert."  Great prices and super friendly staff.  I also noticed they have wonderful classes and if I was in town would definitely sign myself up (great place to impress a date).
I looked at the food offerings and nothing was really speaking to me, but FYI...you can bring other ferry food in to pair with tasty wines.  
Afterwards I walked around the store and loved the fact that there was something amazing for any price point.  This will be a Saturday stop for me to stock up on my weekly wine addiction.
author: Sheila Y.

description:
Hoping to enjoy a wine or two, we seated ourselves at a table to be ignored. Decided to try the bar seating for better service. No such luck After hoping to be waited on or at least acknowledged, four service people washed glasses, waited on a cute young thing, moved rapidly around the bar never looking at us.
We left and will not return. Hopefully, you won't either.
author: Barbara D.

description:
Best place around to get a first rate wine education, great wine tasting and super-knowledgeable/enthusiastic staff. The descriptions on the menu are helpful for what to look for in tasting but also allot about the background or context for the wine or the winery and/or the region as applicable. 

Our most recent experience was with a Riesling flight at the bar. The staff on the store side of things were constantly in motion unpacking things, repacking and moving things around. Its as if they didn't stop to breath. While wrapping up on the bar side, one of us went over to the store side to poke around a bit. All the staff seemed intimately versed on the wines on the bar side and could introduce us to other similar wines or ones more to our liking ("like that other one but drier, please"). Even for things that we had interest or experiences in that they didn't, our attendant had thirst to learn more to add to her own wine knowledge.

We didn't go in expecting to spend a ton on lots of wines (plus our flight and other glass we drank there) but we couldn't help ourselves with all the help they gave us.

I just wish there was more open around them in the ferry building in the evenings. Otherwise, you have to go there as a destination and then get back in the car to go anywhere else. If it was elsewhere, they could have a bigger space and you wouldn't have to feel so cramped in the bar area.
author: David P.

description: I planned my company's holiday party at this place and the staff there was fantastic to work with.  We went in a couple different times and sampled wines for the event.  Amazing selection.  Prices are in line with what you would expect for the Ferry Building.  Overall I was very pleased with this place and will definitely be back for HH.
author: Brian G.

description:
When dining out and coming upon a bottle of  wine that I need to get more of, the ferry plaza wine merchant normally has it.  In addition, to their vast selection of wine and knowledgable staff, you can do wine tasting or enjoy the bottle of wine that  you purchase at the their bar.  You don't have to purchase their cheese plates because they allow you to bring food in.  

Imagine:  Cow Girl Creamery Cheese, bread from Acme, procuitto from Molinari's, and of course wine. 

They also do decent gift baskets for the holidays.
author: Jason A.

description:
We didn't anticipate a wait here on a Saturday morning at 11am.  But the place was PACKED.  We took that as a great sign, and went in ready to wait a bit, get some good wine and food and have some drinks with good friends.  

But once we sat a table, a server came out and told us we had too many for the table (probably true) and that we had to go outside and wait again for an appropriate table.  Since we had more friends coming, we asked if we could keep that table and have some of our group stay there, while the others waited for another table together.  That way we figured it would be easier to split up into little tables rather than wait for a table large enough to fit a huge group.  

But the server didn't want to do that.  Not only did she not want to do that, but she was harsh about it, and a bit rude.  In fact she was mean about the whole thing.  While I"m more than likely to attribute the harshness to the stress of a packed establishment at 11am on a Saturday, she continued to be that way with us despite our efforts to work with her and be understanding of her stress.  

We finally left unhappily.  

I was super disappointed that we didn't get to hang out and enjoy the place that has gotten such great reviews.  

Maybe we need to come back at a less busy time.  But right now I'm sad to say that I have a bit of a sour taste in my mouth about this place.
author: Denise B.

description:
These guys are great -- consistently excellent recommendations on wines by the glass or by the bottle and to drink onsite or take home with you. The staff in the wine shop are extraordinarily (almost unbelievably) helpful and really went out of their way to help us remember the maker of a wine we had there a year prior. (Seriously, they figured it out for us from some random notes about the varietal, flavor, and label. These guys are good!)

 love that you can choose from the huge array of foods that the Ferry Building has to offer and take them to the Wine Merchant to eat while drinking your vino. I wish I worked downtown so I could make this an after-work ritual (or even during lunch?).
author: J C.

description:
Top-class people here. I was standing in line waiting to get some service, but the dude behind the counter was chatting with a customer for a billion hours. Luckily, I received help from someone else who answered my question... answered it with gusto. Very helpful and polite.

Prices range in such a way that there is something for everyone. They have a good selection of wines that I haven't seen in other places.

Pick up a WineSaver for $10 to preserve your wine after the first drink. Inert gases are good!

They offer half-bottles for people like me who don't want to pay $40 for a whole 2000 Bordeaux (the other 2000 was $250!).

Has a place for wine and a place to dine (on wine).
author: Keane L.

description:
I'm finally learning to like wine. Growing up Italian and with connections to the Gallo family, the best we ever got was Turning Leaf, but we usually had some variety of table wine.

Now that I'm grown up, I want to have wines from all over the world, not just the central valley of california. This is the place for it, you want German or Austrian they have it. Try the Vertliner, while I can't tell you what varietal it is, I can tell you it's a white and very good. I can't say the same for the Italian Dolcetto, which means sweet. I've never had a red dessert wine, and I probably never will again. A flight runs about $8 for three tastes.

I'm also a proponent of tastes verses glasses of wine, and most of their tastes are under $5. Drinking wine is about enjoying the flavors and scents, not about getting drunk. That's what vodka is for.
author: Rob H.

description:
Needed a bottle of wine post-work.  A good bottle.  So coworker and I went to Ferry Building, spoke to one of the knowledgeable staff and managed to grab a table.  The wine was good and tasted as described.  Add a cheese board and the night was well on its way.

Only downside was that it took a while (busy Monday night) for one of the guys to take our food order.
author: Anonymouse C.

description: This place is definitely an awesome wine bar with a great vibe and good wine.  It's always crowded because it's a fun place with great wine and small plates.  Try to get there early to grab a spot because it fills up fast.
author: Carly P.

description:
I never come to the Ferry Building. But it was such a treat to have a glass of wine here. I had a glass of white because I wasn't feeling like red. My friend brought in a variety of Italian donuts filled with custard, chocolate, raspberry jam, etc. It was better than having cheese and crackers with the wine. Maybe I was just hungry. 

We were lucky to have gotten a table on a Thursday afternoon. The waiter was very helpful in helping us to pick out a wine that we wanted to try. He was generous with the pour. It got a little noisy because they had an area sectioned off for this small event. But it was fun and I like the festive atmosphere.
author: Candace F.

description: Great, casual wine bar.  Good selection by the glass and bottle, and truly tasty salumi and cheese plates (Cowgirl served with Acme bread, obviously).
author: Melinda C.

description:
Bar:  Love it.  I've had some very excellent wine here at very reasonable prices - recommended by people on the staff.  I like that you can bring in outside food to eat while you're sipping at the bar, and I also really love the cheese plate that they sell.  

Wine store:  love it, too.  Just tell them what you're looking for at what price point, and the staff will give you excellent recommendations.

Gets crowded, and there isn't enough seating, but this is a great afternoon drinking spot any day of the week.
author: Miu M.

description:
Went here for a casual weeknight drink with colleagues. For a Tuesday evening, the place was surprisingly crowded. Last call is around 7ish, however, so the drinking is short-lived (not a bad thing).  Since it positions itself more as a wine merchant than a wine bar, you shouldn't expect great service. Our waiter was neither knowledgeable nor helpful, and a bit unfriendly at times. But I assume that might be an isolated incident.

This place offers a range of wines, which is either a good or bad thing depending on your knowledge of wine. They also offer some cheese and cold cuts to snack on which is nice. The bread is super yum - so yummy that the snack can end up being your dinner for the evening. I definitely enjoyed the place - not your typically SF wine bar. There's definitely character ... something you're more likely to see in Europe or outside the city than here.
author: buggy b.

description:
Any place where you can drink and cut your own cheese is my kind of place.  Friendly staff, great people watching, good wines--and great bottles under $20.

What more could you ask for?

And when I say cut your own cheese, I really mean BRING your own cheese.  I don't condone flatulence in public places.  Just a sidebar....
author: Paul D.

description: Sales associates do not know all cheese pairings.  The selection is overwhelming so you have to know what you want so you can ask for help.  They do not carry Navarro wine grape juice.
author: Ai M.

description:
*Good global wine selection
*Fresh eats brough from throughout the Ferry Building (cowgirl creamery, acme bread, etc etc)
*Great people watching
--All in all a good (oink oink) time
Can I hold one star back for you being enough of a good thing that I must be ninja-like in my attempts to get a table during "happenin" hours, and for the fact that you can't control the closing the parking lot nearby?  I probably shouldn't.
author: Isa L.

description:
Quiet Tuesday, 3 pm.  Ordered a taste of their Rhone Syrah and Paso Robles Syrah.  

The Rhone was flat and tired.  Definitely a stale pour.  Bartender was not at all concerned about our displeasure, and merely stated that they were busy and the wine was never old.  (Yeah, right, all wine bars say that.)  

The Paso Syrah did not taste much like a Paso Syrah.  Turns out it isn't -- it's a blend, only 50% Syrah.  Well, if it's not a Syrah, then why was it explicitly labelled as such on the menu?

Overall, a negative experience with uncaring and uninterested service.
author: Bob B.

description:
Staff - The staff here was amazing except for one staff member, who was so rude that I had to take off one star.  My GF and I went to the Ferry Building on 3/24/12 around noon and after checking out all the vendors, we decided to stop here for a drink.  The place was very busy, but we saw a sign that said "please seat yourself" and saw two open tables.  We went to sit down at one of the tables and one of the employees, male in a red vest with a neatly trimmed beard and short spiky hair told us "Other people are waiting, go get in line" (this is verbatim).  Not even a "please" or "sorry for the confusion, we are a little busier than normal today".  I mentioned the sign that said seat yourself and asked if that was the case.  He then said "just get in line" (verbatim again) and walked away.   This normally would have caused me to walk away, but my GF really wanted to try the place out so we got in line.  While we waited in line, the guy in the red vest came up to the line and said "You all need to move over and keep this area clear for me" then walked away again.  As a former waiter, I know everyone has bad days, but you cannot let your foul mood effect your work and rub off on your customers.  Thankfully, we did not end up in this employee's section.

We did end up with a wonderful server who took the time to recommend some wines from the wine list and told me about the Pilsner on tap was from a European brewer who scoured America looking to expand, but found that the water in Berkley (for some reason) was the only water that could re-create the proper flavor and taste of the beer they brew.  I wish I got our servers name, because he was that amazing.  

Food & Drinks - They have a huge wine & beer selection so there is something on the menu for everyone and the cured meats we got went really well with our drinks.  I could have spent the day there drinking my way through the menu.

Atmosphere - Fantastic.  First, you have to realize that this place is in the Ferry Building which is a very busy place, so if you are looking for quiet and relaxing, this isn't it.  But, it is an awesome place to people watch and drink the day away.

Recommendation - Definitely try this place out.  The beer and wine variety alone are reason enough to come here just make sure you don't get the server with the neatly trimmed beard and short spiky hair.
author: Matthew D.

description:
Thirty years in SF and I'd never been to the Ferry
Building until my favorite jazz singer, Sony Holland,
began doing summer Thursday evening performances.
I just naturally gravitated to the FP Wine Merchant 
before her sets....very nice selection of wines but,
getting a seat, is so-o-o-o-o difficult.  On two 
occasions, I tried recommendations of new 
vintages for me and was very pleased.  I'd like
to go back when everyone is NOT getting off
work...for a more leisurely glass of wine and
to try some of their cheeses.
author: Carmen H.

description:
I came here in hopes of purchasing a bottle of an absolutely fabulous Pinot Noir I enjoyed at Va di Vi recently (Diehrberg Pinot Noir... to die for).  Woe is me!  Apparently the FPWM does sell this product but supposedly the bottles disappear moments after being shelved.  : (

A super friendly, knowledgable salesperson recommended the Calera Pinot instead.  As I walked up to purchase it, another salesperson commented that I would LOVE the Calera Pinot.  Of course I did!  

I have also been here for wines by the glass and I wish their tables were a bit more comfortable and they had more of them!  It was really crowded around 5pm on a Thursday evening.
author: Sheila D.

description:
I love this place.  

I've spent some time here,  typically to meet friends for happy hour.

Only bummer...not enough room.  Difficult to find seating (seat yourself) and is typically packed everyday.  

The shop is great, buy a bottle of wine and open it at the bar.  Save $$.
author: Inga B.

description: The wine is great, the bread, meat and cheese platter is excellent, but oh my the prices can kill your bank account. This place is extremely popular especially when they are doing a tasting. I've been here several times, but this time my friend and I met at 5:30 pm on a Wednesday and I got the last tiny little table for the two of us. I had two glasses, she had three glasses plus the platter was $78! Ouch.
author: Janet P.

description: Great, convenient place to grab a drink with friends ferrying between Oakland and SF. Also good for drinks before dinner @ The Slanted Door. It's always packed though and the prices are definitely not cheap.
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
We had a 30 minutes wait for our ferry and we stopped at this cute and cozy wine store, with a wine bar. 
We were so nicely surprised by the ratio quality/price, especially being eastcoaster used to much more expensive good wine.
I will definitely go back there when back in SF!
author: Chiara L.

description:
Suspicions confirmed:  I get good service here if I'm with my little hot tamale.  If I go there by myself, not so much.

The wine selection is nice, though.  And the mark-ups aren't what you think they would be in the Ferry Building.  If you order a cheese tray for $15, you get the equivalent of a whole wheel of cheese.  But then again, maybe not if I happen to be alone.  Hmmm *squinting eyes*.
author: mcmalaprop ..

description:
This charming spot inside the Ferry Building is a must-go if you happen to be in the area.  There are an asortment of fine european and local wines to choose from while you munch on the perfect snacks to compliment.  

I went with a good friend and we shared an amazing Italian red (sorry, don't remember the name) along with a fresh baguette, a green olive & tomato tapenade along with a fresh block of gruyere cheese.  

There's a cute little dining area that opens into the main market aisle in the building.  It's a breat place to have great food, wine and people watching access! haha! ;)
author: Candice M.

description:
I love coming here on a lazy Sunday with a bunch of friends to drink some wine. Usually I come here with a group and we order a few bottles of vino and one of the cheese/bread/olive plates they have available. Try the epi baguette, it is to die for! The best bread ever and if you like it so much they sell it a few stores down at ACME! 
Very reasonable prices and good people watching.
Also they never try to rush you out of the place so it is very relaxing.
author: Kehaulani K.

description: I came in and didn't really know what what I wanted just in the vein of biodynamic and organic California wines. I got excellent service from Jason who fleshed out my palate and made some good suggestions. He offered me a taste and gave me a little history about my selections. It was agreat experience and I'm excited to share these wines over the holidays.
author: Liri R.

description: I like this place. I wanted to looooove it, but I only like it. Perhaps I am spoiled by my favorite LA wine shops, because this place just doesn't cut it for me the way that DomaineLA and 55Degrees do. Even the Oaks Gourmet seems to have a better selection of mid-range wines. I see this wine merchant more like a smaller-scale K&L...which isn't a bad thing. It's just not for me. I saw a few gems in the higher-end section, and I do appreciate that they carry a ton of value wines under $20 for those looking for that sort of thing. But of all the wines I looked at, I only settled for a 2009 bottle of Barbera d' Alba for $24...just because I was intent on bringing home a bottle of wine from my trip. Ironically, it was an Italian wine so the novelty of bringing home a California red sourced so close to Napa was a fail. With ACME, Cowgirl, and Boccalone next door though, this is the perfect place to pick up a bottle of wine and pack a picnic basket. 3 Stars for their service and selection. Not once did anyone ask me if I needed help with anything...and I was in there for 20 minutes. The lady who checked me out was friendly though.
author: Frances L.

description: Went there on a Tuesday for wine tasting. Really enjoyed Domain Des Roches Cremant de Bourgogne Brut, France. It was so bubbly, and dry! My favorite of all!!! Love the ambiance and service was not bad.
author: Michael-Paggy W.

description: I love a good wine bar. This is a good wine bar. They have a variety of tasting flights available at a range of prices. I recommend doing the current wine club flight with the cheese pairing. They also have a great boccalone salumi plate, a pate plate and several cheese plate options to choose from, like brie and manchego, Cowgirl Creamery Mt. Tam (by the whole or half), Goat cheese and more. They also change up the list every month, so when I visit (about once a month) there's always something new to taste. The wine store is great too, they can be pricey on certain items, but they do have a lot of hard to find vineyards like Yorkville Cellars. It does get crowded, but I've managed to snag seats at the bar most of the time I visit. And they remember you if you come in semi-frequently. A great experience.
author: Jason G.

description: I have been going to the Ferry Plaza Wine Merchant for a number of years now. I thought I would comment on how much I enjoy the wine tasting/cafe. I typically buy a bottle of wine for our table and enjoy a nice selection of cheeses and french bread which "The Joy" brings with us to compliment our wine. It is fun to people watch and enjoy great wines selected by the staff.
author: Gerry C.

description: If you are in the Ferry building then you can easily make your own lunches by stop by a few stores to pick up deli meat, bread, cheese and of course wine and then just go outside and have a nice picnic. The wine store in here has a good selection of wines and you if don't know what to get then asked one of the people who work there. They are more then happy to help. Personally I like the tastering area because hey who doesn't like to get buzz while you are shopping around.
author: John N.

description: Love this place. I live in Sausalito and like to grab a glass before I ride the ferry. Great cheeses and the wines are really fairly priced.
author: elizabeth s.

description: We've been here three times and had really insightful help every time.  Jerry and Deja are helpful and knowledgeable.  We've purchase some great limited quantity bottles and also discovered a few new things (will be eternally grateful for the Jean-Vesselle discovery.)  They also have a descent selection of half bottles (love the Domain Serene Evenstad.)   I'm a much bigger fan of the shop than the bar.  Their by-the-glass selection is surprisingly limited and there are better wine bar options (Nectar).  On the rare occasion that I've been able to apples-to-apples price compare, I didn't find them to be over priced, but it you have to pay to park in the lot across from the Ferry Bldg you better buy enough to make that ridiculous expense worth it.
author: P J.

description: By Ferry Building standards, you gotta give these guys a little credit because the $10 section, while understandably cursory, is at least existent and well-signed.  And, like a good wine shop, you can count on them only stocking stuff they can stand behind.  A handy stop if you're already here, but it's not a destination for me, especially as half the shop is really a wine bar, and even at 11 AM on Saturday it's packed with folks happily chatting and chugging away...I dunno, for some reason I like to peruse my wines and spirits in peace and quiet.
author: Wes M.

description: Good place for an after work drink... good place to have a drink with friends and forget that you've just been laid off. Okay, so the circumstances sucked, but the wine was good and they serve cheese. Wine and cheese make me happy. I had the flight of 4 California wines ($12) and local cheeses ($10 for 4 smallish pieces and some bread). It was satisfying. The service was a little slow, but the place was bustling, so I don't blame them too much and it was fine to just sit and talk anyway and not feel rushed. The Ferry Building is a good setting and the Wine Merchant is a classy but unpretentious place. Thumbs up.
author: Caitlin H.

description: Do yourself a favor...next time you're planning an elaborate meal, swing by the Ferry Plaza Wine Merchant, and ask one of their experts about pairing. I made duck with cherry port sauce, and was at a complete loss with what wine to pair with it. I asked a Ferry Plaza Wine Merchant employee, and she suggested a delightful Muscat table wine, which was beautiful with the dish. This spot is on my "must" list, when I'm shopping at the Ferry Building. Check out their wine club too!
author: Brianne K.

description: Aside from the fact that the selection is varied and I've seen all kinds of good stuff here, what makes this shop stand out are the big signs pointing out 'wines under $10' or 'wines under $20' because for all your grandiose talk about appellations and vintages and pairings I've seen you trying to subtly turn the bottles on the shelf to get a look at the price tags without anyone noticing what you're doing. There's shouldn't be any shame in it.
author: matthew r.

description:
i've been in here a few times now, and each time i'm seriously ignored. once i was even waiting patiently for one of the sales guys to finish with a customer, he looked at me and then walked aways. wtf?! did he think i was just standing there for my health? 

another time i actually went for a glass of wine. it was early and there was no one else at the tasting area, so my friend and i grabbed a table and waited. the guy just stood behind the bar polishing glasses. so, we finally went over to get a wine list. and he just kept polishing. so, finally we went to order the wine and brought it back to the table. so, i thought, ok, maybe there's no table service, although i'm pretty sure i've walked by and seen other people getting served. 

by the time we were leaving the tables were full and everyone was getting served but us. we had to go back to the bar to close our tab. i've pretty much never been back. fine, if you don't want to serve us, we'll just go somewhere else.
author: Angela W.

description: Great alternative to a hustle and bustle happy hour  - I feel like I am in an exploratorium every time I visit!
author: Yelper A.

description: Like this little bottle shop/wine bar. Wasn't as impressed with the cheese plate--there isn't enough variety. Still a good place in SOMA.
author: Wendy B.

description:
an adorable little place that's crazy busy on weekends.  my friends and i stopped in here to get some lunch but realized that in terms of food all they have are wine and cheese, so we went to taylor's and came back for the vino and some people watching.

we had to wait forever for a table, but the staff was super friendly (made some excellent recommendations), and then found us a table themselves (it's supposed to be a seat yourself situation).  i'll definitely be back here soon!
author: Roshni R.

description: A great place to take an out-of-town visitor. Or a date. Or yourself when depressed because no one visits you and you have no dates. There's nothing that says "weekend" or "day off" than knocking back a boutique pinot in the middle of the day with a little epi bread and salami. The FPWM anchors the entire plaza and if you can cop a seat next to the passers-by, it's a great place to watch the world go by and feel a little smug that you have this good seat and a glass of good wine.
author: jim b.

description: Great place to stop in for good wine and a selection of Ferry Bldg food (Golden Gate Meat Company, Cowgirl Creamery, Acme Bread). Pleasant and helpful staff who are happy to spend time with you to ensure a good experience. When you're in the area and need a break or a casual, light dinner - get some!
author: Andy S.

description: I've been in here a few times now looking for specific wines for specific occasions. The staff here are super helpful and super friendly and not at all snobbish about me not wanting to blow more than $20 on a bottle of wine (we *are* in a recession you know!). Definitely a repeat customer.
author: Mi M.

description: What a pleasant surprise. I came to the ferry building for the first time and had no idea it offered so many wonderful things to try. We came upon the Ferry Plaza Wine Merchant and decided to give it a try...I'm glad we did! We decided to try two wine flights (club and private label) as well as a cheese flight, what fun! I really enjoyed trying six different wines from all over in one sitting, they were all delectable. When in the area I would recommend going here, you wont be disappointed!
author: Jason F.

description: a few of us stopped by for a glass of wine on a saturday afternoon, and the wine bar section was packed! after about 10 minutes, we managed to secure a small table. i didn't order any wine, but i perused the wine list. i was a little surprised that there were only a few choices of wine by the glass. i thought it was a cool touch to offer appetizers such as a cheese plate, acme bread, fruit, etc. overall it's a cool concept and i'll probably stop by the next time i'm at the ferry building to buy a bottle of wine from the wine store section. :)
author: Clara K.

description: So, you've just left Hog Island, have some time to kill and everything in the Fi Di is closed b/c it's the weekend. What do you do? Go here. Their selection isn't huge (at the wine bar, the actual store is different), but it covers a wide range. I had a good pinot noir and got the goat cheese round to accompany it. The bread was fresh, as was the cheese. My only qualms were that 1) the cheese was pretty cold (but I guess the health dept. requires that) and 2) that we were served with plastic utensils. That kind of ruined the vibe. But they're pretty reasonable and it's a nice little stop before you have to catch the ferry.
author: Veronica W.

description: The slightly higher price point at Ferry Plaza Wine Merchant is worth every penny because of the impeccable service. The staff is knowledgeable and passionate about wine, but completely approachable. I often ask for help selecting wines and have yet to be disappointed, but what really impresses me is that they remember my preferences on return visits. That's service, people. I also highly recommend their wine club -- two selections per month (never exceeding $38 total), recipes for suggested food-wine pairings, discounts on all wine purchases and at Cowgirl Creamery (!), and access to members-only tasting events.
author: Heather F.

description: Lovely wine and cheese with my two closest girlfriends who got to meet one another tonight for the first time.The cheese and spreads and bread were all really fresh and tasty and the wine spectacular.  Great people watching as they rolled out the fruit in front of us and a band played nearby.  A great evening out.
author: Lauren S.

description: Great for post work glass of wine without the happy hour crowds. Fantastic cheese plates AND you can grab some vino for the house while you're there. Also right on the main drag so it's easy to recruit passers-by to join the fun.
author: Jennifer B.

description: What a fun little place!  Small tastes of wine, fun cheese and bread and meat.  Its hard to beat that.  But note:  You have to stand around like a pathetic little seat vulture in order to get a table or place at the bar.  You feel really stupid staring at people eating and drinking cause they dont have a waiting list or take names...you just have to kind of swoop in right after someone gets up.
author: Cathleya G.

description:
used to work in a wine shop so expectations are high.  love the bar area, good flights and other selections.  great staff, knowledgeable.

i went a few weeks ago and sampled a wine currently not on the menu.  one of the bar people not only remembered me but he remembered where i was sitting and what i was drinking.  He wasn't even my waiter!!!


great range of wine, decent $8 bottles to wine i won't be able to afford for a few more years.  love it!!
author: kiki b.

description:
My wife and I went to the Wine Merchant  after celebrating our 20th anniversary with dinner at Michael Mina, an overnight stay at the Hotel Vitale and lunch at the Slanted Door. Before we left for home we strolled over to the Ferry Plaza and enjoyed a couple of tastes and glasses. The woman behind the wine bar was great and a lot of fun. I can't remember what we ended up buying but  we enjoyed our purchases and the day was fun. 

Part of my infrequent mass transit commute days usually include a stop at the Wine Merchant. You see, I commute from Alameda to Menlo Park and that involves CalTrain and a ride on the Harbor Bay Ferry. Well, the timing of these connections normally leaves me with about 45 minutes to kill at the Ferry Plaza during the evening commute home. By the time I get there it's just before 7PM and most of the places in the plaza are closed, except for the Wine Merchant and the indoor/outdoor bar whose name escapes me. So, since I really like wine it's the perfect opportunity to browse. The wine bar's usually crowded so I just look over the cases and shelves for something interesting. Last week I happened upon a bottle of  a "Neal" cabernet. It was a huge bottle and I didn't want to buy that much since I didn't really know much about "Neal" wines. So, I asked if they had a more normal sized bottle. They did and it wasn't cheap but it didn't scare me enough NOT to buy it. So I did. I haven't tried it yet as I'm saving it for, well, I'm not sure yet. She ("She" being the woman that has helped me on a few occasions there. I'm bad with names.)  assured me it was good and I believe her because she's been good to us so far. Maybe I'll let you know how right she was.

I've enjoyed my visits to the WM and I must say the good folks that serve you there are quite helpful and friendly. That's been my experience anyway. Looking forward to my next commute through there.

UPDATE: Stopped in there Friday evening while waiting for the HBF to arrive for the final leg of my commute home. It was crowded but I found a SRO spot near the register. I didn't have much time so I did a speed tasting of some PInot's on the list. One full glass and one taste.
Both were good but then the guy behind the bar brings me a generous taste of a another Pinot that was really nice with a very generic label. I bought a couple of bottles and headed to the HBF. Now this review wasn't about the wine but just the cool extra pour and the story of how they got the wine. That turned out to be my favorite of the three. If you want to know what it was let me know. I don't have it in front of me to write about it. C'mon I'm at work!

Yet another update!:
Well, you're probably of the opinion that I stop in here frequently. OK, I confess, every time I ride the HBF I roll through there. My excuse(s)?
1) I have time to kill and by the time I get to the ferry plaza everything else is pretty much closed EXCEPT the FPWM.
2) I like wine.
3) Both 1 and 2.
This update is basically that I finally ran into the helpful "she" that 
I mentioned before and asked her name (for the fourth time probably).
Her name is Dina and she's great. I was in a hurry my last pass through, well sort of, I didn't have time to enjoy a glass before the last ferry left. So, Dina recommended a nice inexpensive bottle for the ride
home and told me that I would be calling her to thank her.  It was great and I shared it with a couple of folks on the ferry home. I will thank her when I stroll through there again.

Last night I stopped in to browse and found a bottle that sounded interesting and wasn't too expensive to gamble on. Although it was probably a safe bet since the FPWM review was favorable. However, as usual I was running up against the ferry schedule. I was in line to purchase it but the register malfunctioned briefly while serving another customer. I had to make a decision, miss the last ferry or hang around and buy the bottle. Well, couldn't miss the ferry as that would have been really inconvenient. I'll be back soon anyway.  2005 O'Neil Pinot.
author: Neal A.

description: My favorite place to meet for a glass of wine after work.  The staff is very knowledgeable and friendly, although they usually look entirely too busy.  I love grabbing some cheese, fruit, bread from down the hall to make our own grazings.  The atmosphere is really relaxed, if you're lucky enough to grab a table near the perimeter you almost feel like you're outside on days when you wouldn't dream of sitting out of doors in the City.  Also, I never walk out of there without trying a out one of their great under $20 bottles.
author: Nicole G.

description: Good selection of Californias.  Good viogier.  BAD pinotage.  Their South African selection does not represent what S.A. has to offer and is flat out awful.  Their bordeaux selection was also a bit on the empty side w/ a couple of Chateau Margaux's and some other wines I had never seen before. The staff does not really talk to you.  It is okay.
author: Susan K.

description:
definatley a good place to relax while waiting for your ferry!  

had some yummy crackers & hummus, along with a 1/2 bottle of white wine.  

I had meant to stop in apon my return to pick up some wine to take home, but i was too tired :-(
author: LINDA R.

description: I admit it. I'm 26 years old and I know next to nothing about wine. Even I can walk away with a good bottle after visiting this place. Just ask the staff what's good and you can't go wrong. I have picked up some truly excellent bottles from here all thanks to the helpful staff.
author: Jordan M.

description: Top-notch selection, top-notch prices. I prefer Arlequin, really, but you won't go wrong here.
author: patrick g.

description: I think we made out...got the cheese plate with this awesome olive tapenade and a carafe of wine. It is super busy in the evenings. But we got the table. When I feel like unloading the dough I will definitely try the wine flights, starting at $30.
author: Anita C.

description: This place was nice because we were downtown and wanted to relax.  They have a large wine list.  The cheese plate was good.  I don't know if I would go out of my way to go here.  But if you're downtown and in the area wanting a glass of wine I can't say no.
author: Sabrina A.

description: Fun place to hang out after work, open a bottle or two and people watch! I only wish seating were more comfortable...
author: Gobbledygook C.

description: An excellent selection of wines with very knowledgable salespeople. I'd recommend going for happy hour and doing some of their wine tastings at the bar. It's a great way to people watch if you get a table near the front.
author: Nish N.

description: Great location, wonderful venue, awesome tastings.  HOWEVER, their mark-up is high and selection could be MUCH better.
author: Tara H.

description: Wine galore- just give them your price range and preference (vague, i.e. "something that's red and light" to specific) and they'll recommend (without pretension) a great wine for your pleasure.  I think their prices are pretty reasonable too- they often have price guarantees on specialty bottles.  Service at tables, if you can get one, is friendly and efficient. Yummy snacks like CowGirl cheese of artisan chocolates accompany a perfect after-work glass of whatever  you like.
author: Jenni D.

description: While it can get pretty busy after work, I have a friend that works here and I love going for a few glasses of wine and the yummy cheese plate. The staff is incredibly knowledgeable and after serving you a few selections, they can then help you purchase some bottles to take home. It's a little pricey, but really, so is the rest of the Ferry Building.
author: Emily L.

description: this place is precious- i've been here before but last saturday was so much fun- two of was went and picked out three different cheeses, two went for some fresh bread and we came together at the wine merchant for some delicious wine and a yummy snack. So much fun! relaxed atmosphere- great wine, great company, great food= would so do it all over again!
author: Ricquel N.

description:
I have absolutely no authority whatsoever when it comes to critiquing a wine place, but I rate this place so highly because the people there are more than ok with that.  

In an emotion fueled date with an old friend, I suggested we drink here mostly out of our proximity to the location.  I decided on the 2005 shiraz, a smooth and easy to drink red wine.  She opted for the house Pino Noir which, according to her, was also delicious.  

The staff seemed knowledgeable, and they had a wealth of events to help budding oenophiles learn their way around a wine list.  

The place doesn't really offer anything new or fancy in the way of other wine bars, but I really appreciated the way the wait staff didn't rush us through our drinks or force us to have an accompanying cheese plate just to rake in a bit more cash.
author: Luisa M.

description:
Great wine shop... the guys who work here really know their wine and make great recs.  only slight negative is the long lines for a table if you're at the wine bar ($6 corkage fee).

shout out to Daniel who has never suggested a wine we didn't love.
author: Stacy N.

description: Great place to have some wine, cheese, meat and people watching. This is a great little concept and I fell in love with this place. Service was great. Walking through the ferry building I wanted a little of everything, cowgirl creamery, wine, acme bread and the pig parts...what do you know the wine merchant delivered it all for us! If i lived here I would go here weekly.
author: J F.

description: Yep, my daughter and I also chose to leave no tip whatsoever after absolutely miserable service in the wine bar.  After seating ourselves at a table and waiting a goodly length of time to be noticed, a rather grim-faced gentleman came over and asked what we wanted.  No smile, no greeting, no query as to whether we might have questions...we were both struck by his unpleasant demeanor.  After a while, he came back with the wine, set it down with no words and disappeared.  We were hoping for a glass of water but it was never offered, and we were unable to get his attention until he finally noticed that the wine glasses were empty; at that point we ordered the water with no second glass of wine, which seemed to be an irritation for him to accomplish.  We finished the water and pulled out the credit card, the international behavior for "Yes, we would like to pay now," but our waiter was way too busy carrying on a long conversation with another patron, then clearing dishes from another table, then going back and standing in the bar....after waiting about ten minutes, we got up and went to the bar and paid the tab there.  Although it may be a convenient location, I would much rather leave the Ferry Building and find a more welcoming and less pricey venue to enjoy a glass of wine...we won't be going back there!
author: Aleta K.

description: great local place i hit often on way to catching the ferry so I know the guys BUT for some reason yesterday they decided to step me up to a $19 Pinot!!! Really???  It will be awhile before I head back.  very disappointing.
author: Mike F.

description: Very helpful staff, with a good selection of wines to accompany that perfect piece of cheese you just scored at cowgirl creamery.
author: Stellah D.

description: Absolutely love, love the Wine Merchant. The guys are uber friendly and helpful and are so excited about their wine.  I never feel too intimidated to ask for their advice and have never been disappointed with what they suggest.
author: Tanger T.

description: I didn't see anybody making out, Jeremy, but that doesn't mean I didn't slip our bottle the tongue a few times. You'd expect the location right inside the foodie Vatican would dictate high prices, but we just enjoyed a quite reasonable bottle of chilled rose with our lunch made from market purchases, including a cheese souffle, strawberry and spinach salad, and grilled asparagus.  Very nice folks working here.
author: Kevin S.

description:
this place carries a great selection of wines. from roses--so good when it gets hot--to some nice malbecs from argentina. and you can't find wine from argentina very easily. the selection is so interesting, i can spend an hour just reading labels here. 

i love that they have every price point, from under $10 to over (well, i don't know, i don't spend that much on wine). the point is nice bottles under $10. plus the people that work here are helpful and regular. regular people that like wine. i like them for that. 

get here early if it's later in the week, it fills up during happy hour.
author: rachel p.

description:
short-and-sweet:

nice selection at reasonable prices.

fun place to drop in and do the wine-bar-and-nibbles thing.

*great* wine club to be a member of.  I've been a wine club member at FPWM for a couple of years now, and (besides the good value) have consistently been introduced to faboo wines I never would have purchased on my own.

added bonus: the wine selections come with suggested recipe parings that are not lame.  really.  some of their recipes are very good.  they aren't just plagiarizing crap out of cookbooks.

oh, and the people who work there are really friendly and knowledgeable.  I belong to a few sorta booze-club memberships... from snobby napa BS ones to beer-of-the-month.

FPWM is my fave, by far.
author: Mark B.

description: Most of what I know about wine came from co-owner Debbie Zacharias' wine tasting class at Berkeley. Although she no longer teaches the class, her and the staff at FPWM offer nothing but the best! Debbie is also a co-owner/wine buyer at the San Francisco restaurant Bacar.
author: Philip M.

description: this is not my kind of wine bar.  i have been going since it's inception and yet the offerings are stagant and change infrequently.  SF is at the gateway of infamous wine country's and has not wine that can truly live up to this fact.  i do realise that the lease is probably pricey and that mark-ups slim but i would offer a frequent refresh to the menu.  the service is inconsistent; sometimes great, sometimes touchy and sometimes not to be found.  i think the seating is terribly uncomfortable.  and i wish i could get the enthusiasm i once had for this place to go once more.  i am jonesing for a wine bar a la London, Paris or New York.
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description: I really enjoy this place every time I go.  The selection is great.  I usually go with a group of friends before dinner.  There are a couple different appetizers that are pretty good also.  The best thing about this place is the service.  The people are very friendly and helpful.  Sometimes they even give us random discounts.  I recommend this place highly.  If you are in the area and up for some wine, give it a try.  It is an older crowd, but it's fine if you are in you mid to late 20's.  I would feel out of place under that age.  It is located in the Ferry building.  Parking is kind of pricey, but it's SF.
author: Christopher D.

description: A decent selection of wines sure enough (for me, you can never have too many choices of wine though so I'm ALWAYS looking around for more) in a great, foodie location.  A Saturday afternoon food shopping here is a damned good way to spend a rainy afternoon.
author: Rob M.

description: Very good selection, and if you get on their email list you can find out about the tastings they hold every month or so (often hosted by a winery).  I went to an amazing Flowers tasting a while back, where we tasted some terrific Sonoma Coast Pinot's and Chardonnays, and got a chance to chat it up with the winemaker while doing so.
author: Andrew E.

description: These people know what they're talking about.  The sales associates are really helpful and they have a solid selection of decent bottles in their $10-or-less section.  Great little wine bar too.
author: Alyssa W.

description:
they know what i want. wine. lots of it. even some cheaper ones. please don't suggest anything over $30. i'm in the $15 range. thanks.

and thank you for always having my favorite pinot noir. Three Saints. i'm saving a bottle for a rainy day.
author: Valerie V.

description: Perfect Place to grab a glass or flight of wine, shop around for great local and European wines, munch of cheese/bread/meats...perfect little stop while roaming the stores.
author: Meredith A.

description: Grate wine selection. Friendly service. And the cheese plate was so good.
author: len g.

description: Great service and great selections!  Just ask them what there excited about, and you won't be disappointed!
author: Sarah D.

description: A favorite for a casual drink after work, if you can get a chair (or make that a stool).  If the stools were a bit more comfy, and if the place was a bit bigger (frustrating to be forced over to MarketBar when this place is too crowded) it would get an easy 5 stars.  Nice wines, nice staff, good snacks ... all around fun friendly atmosphere.
author: J P.

description: I was recently there for a Wed. night wine tasting and it was crowded.  However, once we were able to stalk and grab a small table we settled down to enjoy a 5 flight wine tasting with some Acme bread, delish cheeses and olives.  It was pricey, but a wonderful treat.  Def. try it at least once.  Oh - and the staff was great!
author: Annabel G.

description: This is the place for me to go to when I need to pick up a good bottle of wine in the FiDi/Embarcadero area.   They have a pretty extensive bottles of wine of small wineries and their recommendations have been always top notch.  I haven't been disappointed with any of their recommendations that they have there.  Also they also have some great vinophile gadgets there as well.   So it is a recommend for me, but I will stick to my Coit Liquors for the prices.
author: Chris C.

description: Nice wine selection, enjoy that it's in the Ferry Building. Also some yummy nibbles to nosh on while you enjoy your wine & company (olives, cheese, etc.) Nice place to catch up with friends after work to unwind.
author: Abby W.

description: I was so happy to stumble on this place.  I was enjoying the Farmer's Market out side on a beautiful weekday afternoon.  I decided to roam around the One Ferry Building.  The Wine Merchant has an impressive selection.  The staff was great.  I felt that I had been shopping there for ever.  Best part, they are able to ship wine if need be!
author: Christopher P.

description: I wish they had more space to hang out in.  Good location in Ferry Plaza.  Perfect after a day of walking around the farmer's market.
author: Cari G.

description: Great choice of wines, very helpful staff.  The cheese box is wonderful!  Great destination for a happy hour
author: Nellie L.

description: I enjoyed  a self-guided tasting here last night. Friend goes there frequently and has been talking about it, so I joined her. They seem to move a lot of wine- it's really a wine store, and a fourth of it or so is sectioned off for tasting. They had a champagne I recently bought, but not the best one (in my opinion). I like sitting in the super fancy mall that is Ferry Building- and having a big list with good write-ups doesn't hurt either!
author: Anna B.

description: The word pretentious comes to mind, and expensive.  I don't mind paying for a nice bottle of red once in a while but it had better be great.  The cheese plate is fair but did not impress.  Admittedly, coming with friends is a great after work alternative.  It's not my favorite wine bar, because Eos won me over long ago.
author: Angelina J.

description: Every time I've tried to come here for a drink, it's been closed for some function.  I hope the table service isn't like the attitidue I got from the cashiers when buying a couple of gift cards.  Two different cashiers were unfriendly and annoyed during the transactions.  WTF?
author: brewgirl b.

description:
I know I suffer from the frequent 5 star ratings, but this place deserves more than that. Just a few names to start it off:

Drea: knows her wine (and pronounces her Southern European offerings quite well), friendly, approachable, pragmatic, funny and the kind of person you want in your close circle of friends.
Jason in the Wine Bar: busy beyond belief but still remembers you, thinks a moment before making recommendations (based on prior requests, etal), and is basically the kind of personality you wish to serve your wine.
Peter: we miss you. Too much to mention about Peter, but you can visit him at the other location (Oxbow).
Dina: just a rad chick, and I mean that in the ultimate way. Dina knows when to be there and what to bring. She makes standing in line the best thing in life.
And all of the others whose names I don't know directly: we LOVE you guys. Members get a huge discount on wines. Monthly tastings are super fun and worthwhile. All in all I have been so impressed by the offer of this place, from $12 wine to 5x that. The staff deserves huge kudos for all of their helpfulness, knowledge, and salesmanship. This place really rocks in terms of great wine at truly reasonable prices and a super approachable/knowledgeable staff.
author: Margaret K.

description: Great location, fun atmosphere, atrocious wine.  I don't really get how a "wine bar" can serve such terrible swill.  We had three wines.  First one was an OK pinot for $15, the second  a $12 Syrah that was undrinkable, so we sent it back, then got a red burgundy for $11 that was ready for the salad dressing.  Been there maybe 4 times in the past and could tolerate the mediocre wines, but this was the last straw.
author: brock g.

description: Great place to hang out! After a little stroll by the other shops ate Plaza, grab a high table at Wine Merchant, choose your wine (you can buy a different one at their store and drink it at their bar or order from the bar wine list ), order some cheese and a baguette... and be happy!!!
author: K D.

description: Went here the other night with a friend for pre-holiday drinks. Being the Ferry Building, I was a little leery about the prices, but happily, turns out they have a wide range of wines at a wide range of prices. The staff was friendly and knowledgeable, the atmosphere relaxed and warm. No snooty factor here. The cheese board for two was delicious -bread from Acme, marianted olives and mushrooms, and two kinds of cheese. Although the place was pretty crowded, you could carry on a conversation without having to yell. Civilized, intimate, yet casual. A great place to go for a calm after work drink.
author: Madhavi K.

description: I have a habit choosing awful wine on my own, as I have been told by David and Mary, The staff working at the Wine Merchant are well attentive and their knowledge of the wine is plus. I am very happy with the service and the suggestions made by the staff.
author: Raul D.

description: Love this place, but could do without the condescending attitude from the old woman that works there. She claims to try every bottle, but last week we bought a Sav Blanc that could only be described as "overtones of mushroom.' BLECHHH! I don't trust her.
author: John M.
